Person includes individual natural persons, partnerships, joint adventures, societies, associations, clubs, trustees, trusts, or corporations; and any officers, agents, employees, factors, or any kind of personal representatives of any thereof, in any capacity, acting either for himself or for any other person, under either personal appointment or pursuant to law. 
Physical culture establishment means any business establishment which offers or advertises massage, body rubs or physical contact with specified anatomical areas, whether or not licensed. Business establishments which routinely provide medical services by state-licensed medical practitioners and electrolysis treatment by licensed operators of electrolysis equipment shall be excluded from the definition of physical culture establishments. 
Premises means that area in which an adult use is permitted, as well as the outside perimeter of a multiuse structure or building in which the adult use is located. 
Private performance means the display or exposure of any specified anatomical area by an employee of an adult entertainment establishment to a person other than another employee while the person is in an area not accessible during such display to all other persons in the establishment, or while the person is in an area in which the person is totally or partially screened or partitioned during such display from the view of all persons outside the area. 
Public recreation area means a tract of land within the city which is kept for ornament and recreation and which is maintained as public property. 
Residential zoned property means any parcel located within the limits of the city which allows for residential use. 
School includes a premises or site upon which there is a nursery school, kindergarten, elementary school, junior high school, middle school, senior high school, or exceptional learning center. However, the term "school" does not include a premises or site upon which there is an institution devoted solely to vocational or professional education or training or an institution of higher education, including but not limited to a community college, junior college, four-year college or university. 
Special cabaret means any bar, dancehall, restaurant, or other place of business which features dancers, go-go dancers, exotic dancers, strippers, male or female impersonators or similar entertainers or waiters or waitresses who engage in specified sexual activities or display specified anatomical areas or any such business establishment, the advertising for or a sign identifying which uses the terms "adult," "topless," "nude," "bottomless," or other words of similar import. 
Specified anatomical areas means: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered: 
a.  Human genitals or pubic region; 
b.  Cleavage of the nates of the human buttocks; or 
c.  That portion of the human female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; this definition shall include the entire lower portion of the human female breast, but shall not include any portion of the cleavage of the human female breast exhibited by a dress, blouse, shirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing apparel, provided the areola is not so exposed. 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernible turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
Specified criminal act means: 
(1)  An offense under F.S. ch. 794 (sexual battery); 
(2)  An offense under F.S. ch. 796 (prostitution); 
(3)  An offense under F.S. ch. 800 (lewdness; indecent exposure); 
(4)  An offense under F.S. ch. 826 (bigamy; incest); 
(5)  An offense under F.S. ch. 847 (obscene literature; profanity); or 
(6)  An offense under an analogous statute of a state other than this state or under an analogous ordinance of another county or city. 
Specified sexual activities means: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal for tumescence; 
(2)  Acts of anilingus, bestiality, buggery, cunnilingus, coprophagy, coprophilia, fellation, flagellation, masochism, masturbation, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, sadism, sadomasochism, sapphism, sexual intercourse, sodomy, urolagnia or zooerasty and any other acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; 
(3)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock, anus or female breast; or 
(4)  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities set forth in subsections (1) through (3) of this definition. 
Straddle dance, also known as a "lap dance" or "face dance," means the use by an employee, whether clothed or not, of any part of his or her body to massage, rub, stroke, knead, caress or fondle the genital or pubic area of a patron, while on the premises, or the placing of the genital or pubic area of an employee in contact with the face of a patron, while on the premises. 
Zoning authority means the department of planning and development for the city and, where appropriate, the appropriate board of authority of the city. 
(Code 1983, § 25-1; Ord. No. 94-51, § 1, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 95-7, § 1, 2-21-95; Ord. No. 96-22, § 1, 5-21-96; Ord. No. 96-47, § 1, 11-19-96) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 10-27. - Authority. 
This article and this Code are both enacted pursuant to F.S. ch. 166 in the interest of the health, peace, safety, and general welfare of the people of the city. 
(Code 1983, § 25-16; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-28. - Legislative findings. 
(a)  The concerns raised in the whereas clauses listed in Ordinance No. 94-52 and Ordinance No. 93-18 are incorporated in this article by reference. 
(b)  The concerns raised in the findings incorporated by reference in subsection (a) of this section raise substantial governmental concerns. 
(c)  Adult use establishments have operational characteristics which should be reasonably regulated in order to protect those substantial governmental concerns. 
(d)  A reasonable and simple licensure procedure is an appropriate mechanism to place the burden of that reasonable regulation on the owners and operators of the adult use establishments. Further, such a licensing procedure will place an incentive on the owner/operator to see that the adult use establishment is run in a manner that is consistent with the health, safety and welfare of its patrons and employees as well as the citizens of the city. It is appropriate to require reasonable assurances that the licensee is the actual owner/operator of the adult use establishment, fully in possession and control of the premises and the activities occurring therein. 
(e)  Adult use establishments are a pervasively regulated industry making reasonable inspections and administrative searches necessary to enforce regulatory standards. In particular, the city commission finds: 
(1)  Removal of doors on adult booths and requiring sufficient lighting in adult theaters advances the substantial governmental interest in curbing the illegal and unsanitary sexual activity occurring at adult theaters. 
(2)  The prevention of sexual contact between patrons and employees at adult use establishments is unrelated to the suppression of free expression, but serves to address the concerns raised in the findings contained in this section. Although the dancer's erotic message may be slightly less effective from three feet away, the ability to engage in the protected expression is not significantly impaired. 
(3)  Separating dancers from patrons and prohibiting dancers and patrons from engaging in sexual fondling and caressing in adult cabarets would reduce the opportunity for prostitution transactions and thus should deter prostitution. 
(4)  The barring of nudity in public places furthers a substantial governmental interest in protecting order and morality. This does not deprive one of freedom of expression of whatever erotic message conveyed; it simply makes the message slightly less graphic. 
(5)  Requiring that the facilities of adult theaters be constructed of materials that are easily cleanable, that the facilities be cleaned on a regular basis, and that the employees cleaning the facilities take reasonable precautions to avoid contact with possible disease transmitting media is reasonably related to the protection of both employees and patrons from sexually transmitted diseases. 
(6)  Requiring licensees of adult use establishments to keep information regarding current employees and certain past employees will help reduce the incidence of certain types of criminal behavior by facilitating the identification of potential witnesses or suspects and by preventing minors from working in such establishments. 
(7)  The disclosure of certain information by those persons ultimately responsible for the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the adult use establishment is substantially related to the significant governmental interest in the operation of such uses in a manner as to prevent the spread of sexually transmitted diseases and to reduce or eliminate the criminal activity associated with adult uses establishments. 
(8)  It is desirable in the prevention of the spread of communicable diseases and in the investigation of criminal activity to obtain a limited amount of information regarding certain employees who either engage in the conduct which this article is designed to prevent or are likely to be witnesses to such activity. 
(9)  A substantial rational relationship between sexually oriented businesses and sexually related crimes establishes a compelling justification for barring those prone to such crimes from the management of such businesses. 
(10)  The fact that an applicant for an adult use license has been convicted of a sexually related crime leads to a rational inference that the applicant is more likely to engage in conduct in contravention of this article. 
(11)  The barring of a person from participating in an adult use business shall cease when circumstances are indicated to the city that such persons are no longer criminally inclined. 
(12)  Barring of such individuals from management of adult uses for a period of years serves as a deterrent to and prevents the conduct which leads to the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases and to the promotion of that criminal activity associated with adult uses. 
(13)  Because the weight of evidence shows that while adult bookstores/video stores which only sell or rent adult material and have no adult booth/theater component have similar secondary effects as other adult uses, such bookstores do not promote the transmission of sexual diseases. An exemption of such limited adult establishments from the licensure requirements but not the locational requirements of this article is appropriate. 
(f)  The city commission desires to simplify the finding of all adult entertainment establishment regulations by combining them into one portion of the Code which is contained in this article. This will enable the city to provide a copy of all adult entertainment establishment related legislation by reference to one article of this Code. In order to ensure compliance with all requirements for enactment of ordinances relating to rezoning specific parcels of private real property or substantially changing permitted use categories in zoning districts, pursuant to F.S. § 166.041, the city commission has again reviewed all of the evidence previously presented to it with regard to enactment of Ordinance Nos. 93-18, 93-28 and 93-29 and fully and completely incorporates such ordinances fully in this article. 
(Code 1983, § 25-23; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-29. - Purpose. 
The intent of the city commission in adopting this article is to establish reasonable and uniform regulations that will protect the health, safety and general welfare of the people of the city. The provisions of this article, acting alone or together with other applicable ordinances for the city, have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing a limitation or restriction on the content of any communicative materials, including adult material. Similarly, it is not the intent nor effect of this article to restrict or deny access by adults to adult materials or expression protected by the first amendment or to deny access by distributors and exhibitors of adult uses to their intended market. In all matters involving any violation of this article, the burden of proof to establish that violation shall be with the city or applicable city department. 
(Code 1983, § 25-18; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-30. - Construction of article. 
This article shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purpose of licensing and regulating adult entertainment and related activities. Unless otherwise indicated, all sections of this article shall apply equally to all persons, regardless of sex. Masculine pronouns, such as "he," "his," and "him," as employed in this article, shall also be construed to apply to feminine pronouns and neutral pronouns, unless the context suggests otherwise. 
(Code 1983, § 25-17; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-31. - Regulation of obscenity subject to state law. 
For the purposes of this article, it is not the intent of the city commission to legislate with respect to matters of obscenity. These matters are regulated by state law, including F.S. ch. 847, as may be amended. 
(Code 1983, § 25-2; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-32. - Regulation of massage establishments subject to state law. 
For the purposes of this article, it is not the intent of the city commission to legislate with respect to matters of massage establishments. These matters are regulated by state agency, the department of business and professional regulation, board of massage, and by state law, F.S. ch. 480. 
(Code 1983, § 25-3; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-33. - Jurisdiction. 
All territory within the legal boundaries of the city shall be embraced by the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1983, §§ 25-15, 25-110; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-34. - Applicability of other ordinances and sections of Code. 
Nothing contained in this article is in any way intended to relieve any applicant, employee, patron, person, individual, partnership, corporation or other business entity from complying with any other section of this Code and ordinance of the city with regard to the establishment of and operation of any business regulated under this article. 
(Code 1983, § 25-20; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-35. - Location of adult uses. 
(a)  No business entity in which there is any adult use, as provided in this article, shall be located within 300 feet of any residential zoned property or any portion of a mixed use zoning district developed and utilized as residential or within 300 feet of any church, school, child care facility or public recreation area which is validly located or which has received legal authority to be located. 
(b)  No business entity in which there is any adult use, as provided in this article, shall be located within 300 feet of any other adult use. 
(c)  The distance requirements under subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall be measured along a straight line from the nearest residential zoning district or the nearest property line of the church, school, child care facility, public recreation area or adult use to the closest property line of the adult use. In a multitenant or multiuser building, such as a shopping center, the distance requirement shall be measured from the closest portion of the building or structure utilized by the adult use. 
(d)  An adult use shall not be located or permitted on the same premises as a use or business entity that is licensed to sell or serve alcoholic beverages. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit the operation of any business or the performance of any activity prohibited under any other section of this Code. Additionally, nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize, allow or permit the establishment of any business, the performance of any activity, or the possession of any item which is obscene under the judicially established definition of obscenity. 
(Code 1983, § 25-5; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 96-22, § 2, 5-21-96)  
Sec. 10-36. - Public nudity. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in any public place or in any commercial establishment, unless expressly permitted, within the corporate limits of the city to be found in a state of nudity or to expose or exhibit his sexual organs or expose specified anatomical areas. This section, however, shall not be construed to prohibit the exposure of sexual organs in restrooms or in any other place provided or set aside for that purpose. This section shall not be construed to prohibit the wearing of bathing attire on the city beaches. This section shall not be construed to prohibit a mother breastfeeding her baby. 
(Code 1983, § 25-19; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94) 
State Law reference Exposure of sexual organs, F.S. § 800.03.  
Secs. 10-3710-65. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference Administration, ch. 2. 
 
Sec. 10-66. - Responsibilities. 
(a)  Ultimate responsibility for the administration and enforcement of this article is vested in the department of planning and development, the city manager, police department, and, where appropriate, the city commission. 
(b)  The department of planning and development is responsible for granting, denying, revoking, renewing, suspending, and cancelling adult use licenses for proposed or existing adult use establishments and for ascertaining whether a suspected adult use establishment is licensed or whether a license establishment complies with or is complying with this section, sections 10-186, 10-187, 10-190, 10-191, 10-19310-198, 10-22610-232 and division 3 of this article. The police department is responsible for all enforcement actions brought under sections 10-226 and 10-22810-232 and division 3 of this article. The department of planning and development shall assist the police department in its investigative responsibilities and shall initiate investigations and issue citations in their respective areas of responsibility. 
(c)  The chief of police is responsible for verifying information contained on an application pursuant to subsection 10-187(b), for inspecting any proposed, licensed or nonlicensed establishment in order to ascertain whether it is in compliance with applicable local ordinances and criminal statutes, including the provisions set forth in sections 10-226, 10-22810-232 and 10-23410-245 and division 3 of this article. 
(d)  The department of planning and development is responsible for the inspection of licensed premises and premises for which application for a license is made to ascertain compliance with: 
(1)  All fire prevention codes, statutes or ordinances in effect in the city; and 
(2)  City and county health codes and applicable state laws and regulations. 
(e)  The department of planning and development is responsible for ascertaining whether an existing adult use or a proposed establishment for which application for a license is being made complies with all locational requirements of section 10-35, of Ordinance No. 94-52 and all other zoning regulations and other applicable land use laws of the city and, if it complies, issuing an approval in the form of a valid adult use permit pursuant to sections 10-226, 10-22810-232 and division 3 of this article. 
(f)  Any employee of the departments referenced in subsections (a) through (e) of this section who is authorized by the head of that department shall, at any reasonable hour, which term shall include all hours of operation of the adult entertainment establishment, have access to and shall have the right to inspect the premises of all licensees under this article for compliance with any or all of the applicable codes, statutes, ordinances, and regulations in effect in the city and within the responsibilities of their respective departments, as outlined in subsections (a) through (e) of this section. Such employee shall require strict compliance with this article. Reports of violations shall be reported to the department of planning and development. 
(Code 1983, § 25-41; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-67. - Suit for violations. 
In addition to any penalties for violation of this article, the city can bring suit. The city commission may authorize the filing of suit in the circuit court to restrain, enjoin or otherwise prevent the violation of this article. 
(Code 1983, §§ 25-14, 25-109; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-68. - Immunity from prosecution. 
The city or any department shall be immune from prosecution, civil or criminal, for reasonable, good-faith trespass upon an adult use establishment while acting within the scope of its authority under this article. Any applicant for or holder of a permit required in this article shall, by acceptance and receipt of the permit, agree to be bound by the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1983, §§ 25-13, 25-108; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-69. - Notice. 
Any notice required under this article shall be accomplished by sending a written notification by certified mail to the mailing address set forth on the application for the license or a permit or by personal service. This mailing address shall be considered the correct mailing address unless the department of planning and development has been otherwise notified in writing. 
(Code 1983, §§ 25-12, 25-107; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-70. - Review of decisions. 
Any decision of department of planning and development pursuant to division 3 of this article shall be reviewed as a matter of right by the circuit court upon the filing of an appropriate pleading by an aggrieved party, within 30 days of the action so taken by department of planning and development. 
(Code 1983, § 25-106; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-71. - Penalties and enforcement. 
(a)  Whomever violates any section of this article shall be prosecuted and punished as provided by section 1-14. In all matters involving any violation of this article, the burden of proof to establish that violation shall be with the city or applicable city department. 
(b)  In addition to the penalty provided for in section 1-14, adult bookstores, adult theaters, special cabarets, physical culture establishments or adult photographic or modeling studios not in conformity with the requirements shall be subject to the appropriate civil action, including injunctive relief, in the court of appropriate jurisdiction, for their abatement. Each day that any irreparable or irreversible violation is committed shall constitute a separate offense. Violations of general provisions is subsections 10-226(5)(7) or the applicable special requirements of sections 10-229 through 10-232 shall constitute separate offenses after the time period under subsection 10-197(a) has lapsed. 
(c)  It is the responsibility of the licensee, owner, employee or operator of an adult use business establishment to ensure compliance with this article, notwithstanding the issuance of an occupational license, building permit, zoning clearance or any other governmental permit. 
(d)  If the event the city attorney is required to participate in the prosecution of any violation of this article or if the city attorney is required to engage in any civil action, including but not limited to proceedings for injunction or to recover damages, the holder of the adult use permit involved in such action by the city attorney shall be required to reimburse the city for all attorney's fees paid by the city. Further, any adult use permit holder, by applying for and accepting an adult use permit shall have agreed to and accepted this subsection 
(Code 1983, §§ 25-10, 25-11, 25-94; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-72. - Rebuttable presumptions; affirmative defenses. 
In prosecutions for violations of section 10-236, 10-241 or 10-242, it is a rebuttable presumption, where relevant, that the person with whom the charged individual is alleged to have performed the prohibited act is not an employee. It is an affirmative defense, where applicable, that individuals involved in the alleged violation are employees of the adult entertainment establishment or adult use with whom the otherwise prohibited act is allowed. 
(Code 1983, § 25-95; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Secs. 10-7310-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - EMPLOYEE OF ADULT USE BUSINESS PERMIT 
 
Sec. 10-101. - Required. 
Unless specifically excluded in this division, it shall be unlawful for any person to obtain employment in an establishment licensed or permitted to operate under this article, for any form of consideration, or to exhibit or display specified anatomical areas in an establishment licensed or permitted to operate under this article unless and until such person shall have first obtained an adult entertainment permit or temporary permit from the director of planning and development. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(a); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-102. - Violations. 
Any person who violates this division or otherwise fails to secure a permit as required by this division shall be prosecuted and punished in accordance with general law. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(g); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-103. - Application. 
(a)  All employees of an adult entertainment establishment shall file an application for an adult entertainment permit with the director of planning and development. 
(b)  There shall be submitted with each application for a permit proof of the applicant's age. Such proof shall be provided by production of the applicant's driver's license or passport or certified copy of his birth certificate. If the applicant is unable to furnish such documents, a certificate from the public school authorities as to the age of the applicant upon entering school, as required by F.S. § 232.03, or the school authorities of the state where applicant enrolled in school shall be submitted. Upon inability of the applicant to establish a birth date, the date shall be established in the order of preference as provided by F.S. § 232.03. However, uncertified copies of such documents shall not be accepted. 
(c)  Any applicant who does not possess a driver's license, passport or certified copy of his birth certificate may obtain a temporary permit upon completion of all other requirements for an applicant and submission of a written request to the appropriate authority in his state of birth that certified evidence of his date of birth be provided to the department of planning and development. 
(d)  Any adult entertainment establishment holding a valid adult entertainment license issued pursuant to this article shall be permitted to provide its employees with current permit applicant forms approved by the director of planning and development and to take the photograph of the applicant in a manner and with equipment approved by the city manager on the condition that the establishment: 
(1)  Require the employee to complete the application form and be photographed within one working day of the time the employee begins to work or perform in the establishment; 
(2)  Mail a notice in writing to the director of planning and development within one working day that the employee has begun to work or perform at the establishment; 
(3)  Make the employee available for fingerprinting at a time and location to be determined by an agent appointed by the director of planning and development, at which time and place the employee shall present to the agent the employee's completed applicant form and photograph; 
(4)  On the first Monday of every month provide the department of planning and development with a current listing of all employees and their positions; 
(5)  In exchange for acceptance of the benefits provided by this subsection, waive any and all rights to challenge the permit requirements of this article; 
(6)  Reimburse the city for reasonable additional expenses incurred pursuant to this subsection; and 
(7)  Be liable for damages to the city of $250.00 per day per violation if any employee who performs in the establishment is not entitled to a permit. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(c)(2), (6), (8); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-104. - Age. 
Employees of a licensee on a premises licensed under this article shall not be less than 18 years of age. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(b); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-105. - Fee. 
Every application for a permit required under this division shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee established by resolution of the city commission and which is in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(c)(3); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-106. - Health. 
The director of planning and development shall submit the name of every applicant for an adult entertainment permit who intends to work in an adult establishment to the county health department. If, in the 30 days immediately preceding submission of an application, such applicant was a known carrier of any notifiable communicable disease, as defined in chapter 10D-3, Florida Administrative Code, the county health department shall notify the director of planning and development, and no permit shall be issued unless and until the applicant presents a statement from a licensed physician certifying that the applicant is free of all notifiable communicable diseases. Any person applying for an adult entertainment permit shall be deemed to have consented to having the county health department notify the director of planning and development if the applicant is a known carrier of a notifiable communicable disease and shall be deemed to and shall have waived any right he may have to maintain the privacy or confidentiality of such information. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(c)(4); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-107. - Temporary permit issuance. 
At the time an applicant applies for a permit required under this division and completes all requirements for the issuance of a permit, he shall be issued a temporary permit valid for seven days. No later than seven days from the filing of an application and, if applicable, upon presentation of the statement of a licensed physician as required in section 10-106, the department of planning and development shall issue a permit. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(c)(5); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-108. - Issuance. 
(a)  Under this division, it shall be the duty of the director of planning and development to issue the applicant a written permit, which shall be signed by the director and shall bear the name, all aliases, address, sex, age, signature, and photograph of the applicant. The director of planning and development shall request an applicant to provide such additional information as is necessary to effect the purposes of this article. Upon delivery of the permit to the applicant, the applicant shall be entitled to begin working on the licensed premises as a permanent employee. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued when its issuance would violate a statute, ordinance, law or when an order from a court of law prohibits the applicant from obtaining an adult entertainment permit in the city. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(c)(6), (7); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-109. - Possession required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an employee, as defined in this article, to work, perform or to exhibit or display specified anatomical areas in an adult entertainment establishment without an adult entertainment permit in immediate possession at all times. 
(b)  No person charged with violating this division shall be convicted if the person produces to the director of planning and development, within 72 hours of detention or in court, a permit theretofore issued. 
(c)  Upon receipt of a properly authenticated notification from the director of planning and development verifying issuance of a valid permit, the clerk of the court is authorized to dismiss such case at any time prior to the defendant's appearance in court. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(f); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-110. - Expiration and renewal. 
A permit issued under this division shall expire two years from the date of issuance. A permittee under this division shall be entitled to a renewal of the permit as a matter of course, except when the permit has been suspended or revoked, upon presentation of the previous permit or presentation of an affidavit as to its loss or destruction to the director of planning and development and payment of a fee made payable to the city. The fee shall be established by resolution of the city commission and is listed in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(e); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-111. - Revocation. 
If a permit required under this division shall be issued as a result of false information, misrepresentations of fact or mistake of fact, it shall be revoked. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(d); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-112. - Suspension. 
(a)  Procedure. Upon receiving notice that a jury or other trier of fact in a court of law has found that a person who has been issued a permit under this division violated any section of this article, whether or not an adjudication of guilt has been entered, the department of planning and development shall suspend the permit, and notice of the suspension shall be sent to the address on the permit application, which shall be considered the correct address. 
(b)  Periods of suspension. A single violation of this article shall result in the suspension of the adult entertainment permit for 30 days. Upon a second violation of this article within a period of two years from the date of a prior violation of this article, but not including any time during which the permit was suspended, the permit shall be suspended for 90 days. Upon a third violation of this article within a period of two years from the first of three violations, but not including any time during which the permit was suspended, the permit shall be suspended for 180 days. All periods of suspension shall begin on the 15th day from the date the department of planning and development mails a notice of suspension to the permittee or on the date the permittee delivers the permit to the department of planning and development, whichever comes first. 
(c)  Surrender of permit required. If a permittee, after having been mailed notice of the suspension of the permit in the manner provided in this section, fails to surrender the permit to the department of planning and development within 15 days, the period of suspension of the permit shall be extended and shall not expire until a period has elapsed after the date of surrender of the permit or after the date of expiration of the permit, whichever comes first, which is identical in length with the original period of suspension. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(h); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-113. - Appeal. 
Under this division, if an application for a permit is denied or if a permit is suspended or revoked, the procedures specified in section 10-199 shall be available to the applicant or permittee, in the manner therein specified. If the applicant or permittee does not appeal the denial, suspension or revocation of a permit, the applicant or permittee shall be deemed to have failed to have exhausted the administrative remedies. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(i); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-114. - Change of address, name or place of employment. 
Whenever any person, after applying for or receiving an adult entertainment permit required under this division, shall move from the residential address named in such application or in the permit issued to such person or when the name of the permittee is changed by marriage or otherwise or when the permittee takes on employment or begins to perform at an adult entertainment establishment not indicated in the person's application, such person shall, within ten days thereafter, notify the department of planning and development in writing of such person's old and new address or of such former and new names. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(k); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-115. - Replacement of lost permits. 
Under this division, replacement of a lost permit shall be obtained by completing an application as required in sections 10-103 and 10-10510-107. Every application for a replacement permit shall be accompanied by a fee, which shall be established by resolution of the city commission and which is listed in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1983, § 25-72(j); Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Secs. 10-11610-145. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - ADULT USE BUSINESS PERMIT 
 
Sec. 10-146. - Required. 
No adult use business shall be allowed to commence or continue to operate without first obtaining a valid adult use permit. Any person desiring to locate, operate or continue operation of any adult use shall be required to obtain an adult use permit from the director of planning and development before the establishment or commencement of business as an adult use. 
(Code 1983, § 25-6(a); Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-147. - Application. 
The applicant for an adult use business permit shall complete an application on forms supplied by the department of planning and development for a permit to operate an adult entertainment establishment, which provides the following information: 
(1)  If the applicant is an individual, the applicant's legal name as well as any aliases. If the applicant is a partnership, the full name of all partners, whether general or limited, as well as any and all aliases of the partners. If the applicant is a corporation, the exact corporate name and state of incorporation and the names and aliases of all officers, directors and stockholders. 
(2)  The name under which the business is to be operated and a general description of the services or goods to be provided. 
(3)  The telephone number of the business. 
(4)  The street address of the proposed or existing adult use. 
(5)  Legal description of the property occupied by the proposed or existing adult use, including the property boundaries. 
(6)  A map showing the known locations of any churches, schools, child care facilities, public recreation facilities or other existing or proposed adult uses within approximately 300 feet of the proposed or existing adult use location for which the adult use permit is being sought. 
(7)  If the applicant is not the record owner of the subject parcel, inclusion of a letter, with the notarized signature of the record owner, purporting to be the record owner, and stating the applicant is authorized to seek an adult use permit for the premises. 
(8)  A plan or diagram showing the configuration of the premises, including a statement of the total floor area to be occupied by the adult use business in relation to the gross floor area. The plan or diagram need not be professionally prepared, but must be drawn to a designated scale. Site and development plans shall comply with article IV of chapter 134. 
(9)  Disclosure of any criminal convictions within the previous five years of the owner, manager, clerk or operator, partner, officer, directors or stockholders, as defined in subsection (1) of this section. 
(Code 1983, § 25-6(b)(2); Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-148. - Fee. 
(a)  In order to obtain an adult use business permit, the applicant shall remit to the city a fee for each adult entertainment establishment permit that is issued, which fee shall be separate and distinct from business licenses, occupational licenses or other building licenses or fees. The fee shall be set by the city commission and shall be reasonably calculated to cover the costs of administrating the permitting requirements of this division and shall not be refundable if the application is rejected. 
(b)  The annual application fee for an adult use business permit shall be as established by resolution of the city commission, which fee may be changed from time to time as deemed appropriate by the city commission and which is included in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1983, §§ 25-6(b)(1), 25-8; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-149. - Criteria for issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a completed application for the permit required under this division, the director of planning and development or his designee or any person designated by the city manager shall inspect the proposed location of the adult use; shall check the distance between the lot lines of the adult entertainment establishment and any other adult entertainment establishment, church, school, residential zoned district, residential use within a multiuse zoning district or public recreation area; and shall check the total floor space occupied by the adult use aspect of the business in relation to the total floor area of the business. 
(b)  The director of planning and development may, but only with the written consent of the applicant, extend that period of time for purposes of clarification of issues raised by the review, but in no event shall the time be extended for a period of time in excess of 45 days. 
(c)  The city shall have a check made by the police department for any convictions within the previous five years of any owner, manager, clerk, operator, partner, officer, director or stockholder of the applicant for any of the following crimes: 
(1)  Sexual battery, F.S. § 794.011 et seq. 
(2)  Prostitution, F.S. ch. 796. 
(3)  Lewdness, F.S. § 800.02 et seq. 
(4)  Sexual abuse of child, F.S. § 415.513 et seq. 
(5)  Incest, F.S. § 826.04. 
(6)  Commercial exploitation of nudity, section 6-66 et seq. of this Code. 
(d)  No permit shall be issued if any owner, manager, clerk, operator, partner, officer, director or stockholder of the applicant has been convicted within the previous five years of any of the crimes outlined in this section. 
(Code 1983, § 25-6(c)(e); Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-150. - Issuance of certificate of compliance or noncompliance. 
(a)  Generally. Inspection in the review of the application as stated in this division shall be completed and the city shall issue, within 45 days, a certificate of compliance or a certificate of noncompliance. 
(b)  Certification of noncompliance. 
(1)  When it is found that the location proposed in the application does not meet the distance requirements of subsection 10-35(a) or is one where a valid adult use exists or is one where a valid adult use permit or valid certification of compliance has been issued for another adult use, the location of which is within the distance requirements of subsection 10-35(b) from the proposed location, the applicant shall be notified of the certification of noncompliance of the proposed location with the locational requirements of this article. 
(2)  Upon receipt of the certification of noncompliance, the applicant shall have ten days to appeal the decision on noncompliance pursuant to section 10-157. 
(c)  Certification of compliance. 
(1)  When it is found that the applicant's proposed location meets the distance requirement of subsection 10-35(a) and where no valid adult use exists or where no valid adult use permit or valid certification of compliance has been issued for another adult use, the location of which is within the distance requirements of subsection 10-35(b) from the proposed location, the applicant shall be notified of the certification of compliance of the proposed location with the locational requirements of subsections 10-35(a) and (b). 
(2)  Upon notification, the applicant shall have 20 days to obtain the adult use permit, signed by the director of planning and development or his designee. Failure to obtain that permit within the 20-day time period invalidates the certification of compliance and the applicant must reapply. 
(Code 1983, § 25-6(f)(1), (2); Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-151. - Conflicting applications. 
(a)  The city commission recognizes the potential of creating nonconformities by granting adult use business permits that conflict because the applications are submitted at the same time and the applicants seek permits for the same location or for a location, which, if permitted under this division, would render the other location unusable. The director of planning and development shall develop a system for tracking potentially conflicting applications and for ranking them by date and time of application/date of establishment. 
(b)  Between two applications being processed at the same time, which individually qualify under subsections 10-35(a) and (b) but would violate subsection 10-35(b) if both were to receive permits, the application which was completed at the earliest date, as provided in sections 10-147 and 10-148, shall be notified that the applicant's proposed location has been certified in compliance pursuant to subsection 10-150(c). Applications shall be processed on a first come, first served basis if properly received and properly completed. 
(c)  The conflicting applicant shall be notified of the application's certification of noncompliance pursuant to subsection 10-150(b) with the notation that the noncompliance was due to the earlier submittal of a conflicting application. 
(d)  The first applicant who has received the certification of compliance shall have 20 days to secure the adult use permit, signed by the director of planning and development. If the period of validity of the certification of compliance expires, pursuant to subsection 10-150(c)(2), the applicant must reapply. 
(e)  Any applicant who has received a certification of noncompliance pursuant to subsection 10-150(b) may use the applicant's prior application date in a resubmission for the purposes of establishing the prior date if the original application was made no more than seven months previous. Otherwise the applicant shall submit a new application. 
(Code 1983, § 25-6(f)(3); Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-152. - Contents. 
All permits issued under this division shall contain a legend on the back or reverse which shall state as follows: 
The undersigned permit holder acknowledges that the secondary effects of the operation of an adult entertainment facility are so adverse that should the holder of this permit or any of his/her/their/its agents and employees violate any of the provisions of Section 10-155(a)(1), (2) or (3) or permit a violation to exist, knowingly or otherwise, on the premises of said adult use facility, then the City of St. Pete Beach shall be entitled to issue a cease and desist order as specified by Section 10-155(b) of this Code; and further, the City shall be entitled to revoke the permit issued herewith, and direct that said adult usage be terminated immediately upon issuance of any order of revocation by the City. 
	/s/   
      Permit Holder 
 	 
(Code 1983, § 25-6(f)(7); Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-153. - Validity. 
(a)  The adult use permit issued under this division, signed by the director of planning and development, shall be valid for a period of six months after issuance, during which time the applicant's adult use business must either operate as an adult use or the necessary building permits to establish the adult use business must have been obtained. The validity of such a permit shall be extended by the director of planning and development one time for 90 days for good cause shown. Any decision to deny such an extension may be appealed pursuant to the provisions of section 10-157. 
(b)  Once established, the adult use permit shall remain valid unless revoked by the director of planning and development or the adult use has been voluntarily discontinued for a period of 30 days or more. 
(c)  Decisions by the director of planning and development to revoke an otherwise valid adult use permit may be appealed pursuant to section 10-157. 
(Code 1983, § 25-6(f)(4); Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-154. - Transferability. 
A permit required under this division shall be issued only in the name of the approved applicant and shall not be transferable to any person. 
(Code 1983, § 25-6(f)(5); Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-155. - Revocation and cease and desist order. 
(a)  The city shall be entitled to and shall, in fact, be obligated to issue a cease and desist order to any person holding a permit under this division, requiring the permit holder to immediately cease and desist operation of the adult entertainment establishment authorized in accordance with this article and, additionally and not as an alternative to the cease and desist order, the city shall revoke the permit of any permit holder for any one or more of the reasons set forth as follows: 
(1)  The owner or operator of the permitted business knowingly allowed a person under the age of 18 years of age to be an employee of the adult use business or should have known after reasonable inquiry that the employee was under the age of 18 years. 
(2)  The owner of the permitted business knowingly gave false, fraudulent or untruthful information on the application for such a permit. 
(3)  The conviction of the owner, manager, clerk or operator, partner, officer, director, or stockholder of any criminal violation related to the operation of the adult use business. 
(b)  The cease and desist order shall be issued in order to protect the health, welfare and safety of the citizens of the city from any of the secondary effects of the adult use. The order shall specify the reason for its issuance, and shall also set a time and place for a hearing before an administrative hearing officer, selected by the city manager, in order to determine whether or not the permit shall be revoked. The administrative hearing officer shall hold the hearing required under this subsection within ten business days from the date of the issuance of the cease and desist order. At the hearing, the city shall present such evidence as it deems appropriate to establish the nature of the offense and to establish the reasons for the cease and desist order. The permit holder shall present such evidence as he deems appropriate. Thereafter, the hearing officer shall determine whether to revoke the permit or to place such additional lawful restrictions on the permit holder as shall be necessary in order to ensure that no further violations of this article shall occur. A permit holder may continue to operate until the hearing officer has rendered a decision. A permit holder who continues to operate the adult entertainment facility after a revocation shall be subject to a fine of $500.00 for each day of the violation, which fine shall be determined by the hearing officer at a subsequent hearing. Any fine assessed by the hearing officer shall be recorded as a lien in the public records of the county and in any other county in which the permit holder may own real property or may operate an adult entertainment facility and shall be subject to enforcement and collection in the same manner as any mechanic's lien may be enforced in accordance with F.S. ch. 713, including the right to collect a reasonable attorney's fee. By applying for and accepting an adult use permit, the permit holder agrees to be bound by any and all decisions rendered by the hearing officer. The administrative hearing officer shall conduct a fair and impartial hearing, keeping in mind the requirement of providing due process of law to all parties. In any proceeding regarding revocation of a permit or regarding a cease and desist order, the burden of proof shall be with the city or the applicable city department. 
(Code 1983, § 25-6(f)(6); Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-156. - Variances. 
(a)  If an applicant receives a certification of noncompliance because the location of the proposed adult use is in violation of the locational requirements of this article, and if the applicant wishes to seek a variance from these locational requirements, the applicant shall, not later than ten calendar days after receiving notice of the certification of noncompliance, file with department of planning and development a written request for a variance from the locational restrictions of section 10-35. 
(b)  If the written request is filed with the director of planning and development within the ten-day limit, the director shall schedule a hearing before the city's appropriate board of authority, which body shall consider the request for a variance. The department of planning and development shall set a date for the hearing within 60 days from the date the written request is received. 
(c)  The appropriate board of authority shall hear and consider evidence offered by any interested person in a public hearing scheduled with public notice. Public notice shall be pursuant to the requirements of the Government-In-The-Sunshine Manual. The appropriate board of authority may, in its discretion, grant a variance, with reasonable conditions, from the locational restrictions of section 10-35 if it makes the following findings: 
(1)  A sufficient physical barrier separates the adult use establishment, for which a variance is being sought, from the land use which has caused the adult use not to be in compliance with the distance requirement of this article, so as to substantially fulfill the purpose of the distance requirement. Such physical barriers include but are not limited to limited access streets or highways, walls, natural or manmade waterways. 
(2)  The strict application of this article will work an undue hardship unique to the applicant for a particular location. 
(3)  All other applicable sections of this article will be observed. 
(d)  The appropriate board of authority shall only grant a variance to this article by the affirmative vote of four members. Failure to reach a four-member vote shall result in a denial of the variance. The decision of the appropriate board of authority shall be final. 
(e)  If appropriate board of authority denies the variance, the applicant shall not be entitled to reapply until at least six months have elapsed since the date of the board's action. 
(f)  The grant of a variance does not exempt the applicant from any other sections of this article, other than the locational restrictions of section 10-35. 
(Code 1983, § 25-7; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-157. - Appeals. 
Notwithstanding any other section of this Code or ordinance or section of this article, appeals shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  The appropriate board of authority shall have the authority to hear appeals from decisions made by the department of planning and development pursuant to subsections 10-35(a) and (b) or section 10-156. 
(2)  Applications for appeals of the decisions shall be submitted to the department of planning and development. Applications need not be in any particular form but should reference the application reference number and, generally, the basis for appeal of the decision. 
(3)  The written notice of appeal shall be submitted within seven days of the official notification by the city of its finding. The appropriate board of authority shall consider the appeal and shall issue its finding within 60 days after receipt of the written notice of appeal. 
(Code 1983, § 25-9; Ord. No. 94-52, § 1, 11-15-94)  
Secs. 10-15810-185. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 10-186. - Required; classification. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  No adult entertainment establishment shall be permitted to operate within the corporate limits without first having been granted an adult use license under this article, unless otherwise exempted. 
(2)  Provided it is not in violation of chapter 134 pertaining to zoning, an adult entertainment establishment shall be granted a conditional right to operate within ten days of filing an application for an adult entertainment license. The conditional right to operate shall be valid for so long a time as is necessary for the director of planning and development to issue or to deny issuance of the license. The applicant's conditional right to operate shall terminate five days after the mailing of a notice of denial or preliminary denial by the director of planning and development as provided in section 10-190. Further, issuance of a conditional permit shall not obligate the city or the department of planning and development to grant any other permit for an adult entertainment establishment. Prior to issuance of a conditional permit, the holder for such permit shall be required to sign a written statement to the effect that the permit holder understands the permit is conditional and shall not be reissued or given permanent status. 
(b)  Classifications. Any adult use shall be classified as follows: 
(1)  An adult bookstore or adult video store. 
(2)  Adult dancing establishment. 
(3)  Adult motel. 
(4)  Adult theater, which shall include adult arcades, places or buildings having adult motion picture booths, places or buildings having a hall or auditorium for the presentation of film material and places designed to permit viewing by patrons seated in automobiles. 
(5)  Adult photographic studio or modeling studio. 
(6)  Adult massage establishment. 
(7)  Physical culture establishment or special cabaret or any combination of these uses based on the information in the application subject to subsequent inspection for verification. 
(8)  Adult bottle club. 
(c)  Contents. Each application for a license shall state the classification and location for which it is to be issued. A license shall be issued for only one location and for only one classification of adult entertainment, as defined in subsection (b) of this section, at a single location. 
(Code 1983, § 25-42; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-187. - Application. 
(a)  Required. Any individual, partnership or corporation desiring to operate an adult use establishment shall file with the department of planning and development a sworn license application and a standard application form supplied by the department of planning and development. 
(b)  Contents. The completed application shall contain the following information and shall be accompanied by the following documents: 
(1)  If the applicant is: 
a.  An individual, the individual shall state his legal name and any aliases and submit satisfactory proof that he is 18 years of age; 
b.  A partnership, the partnership shall state its complete name and the names of all partners having either direct, managerial, supervisory or advisory responsibilities for day-to-day operations of the adult use and whether the partnership is general or limited; or 
c.  A corporation, the corporation shall state its complete name, the date of its incorporation, evidence that the corporation is in good standing, the names and capacity of all officers, directors, and stockholders having either direct, managerial, supervisory or advisory responsibilities for day-to-day operations of the adult use and, if applicable, the name of the registered corporate agent and the address of the registered office for service of process. 
(2)  If the applicant intends to conduct the establishment under a name other than that of the applicant, the establishment's fictitious name and a certified copy of the applicant's registration with the division of corporations of the department of state under F.S. § 865.09. 
(3)  Whether the applicant or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section have, within the five-year period immediately preceding the date of the application, been convicted of a specified criminal act and, if so, the specified criminal act involved, the date of conviction, and the place of conviction. 
(4)  Whether the applicant or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to subsection (b)(1) or (2) of this section have had a previous license or permit, under this article or any other ordinance regulating adult uses, suspended or revoked or has been, by any federal or state court order, required to cease operation, including the name and location of the establishment for which the license was suspended or revoked, as well as the date of the suspension or revocation, and whether the applicant or any other individuals listed pursuant to subsection (b)(1) has been a partner in a partnership or an officer, director or principal stockholder of a corporation whose license, under this article or any other ordinance regulating adult uses, has previously been suspended or revoked, including the name and location of the establishment for which the license was suspended or revoked, as well as the date of the suspension or revocation. 
(5)  Whether the applicant or any other individuals listed pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section hold any other license under this article and, if so, the name and location of such other licensed establishment. 
(6)  The general nature of the type of adult use for which the applicant is seeking a license, including a statement concerning the degree to which the anticipated activities at the adult use meet the definitions of the enumerated adult use classifications listed in subsection 10-186(b). Such a characterization shall serve as an initial basis for the permitted activities allowed under the license issued as well a basis for the fee charged. 
(7)  The location of the proposed establishment, including a legal description of the property site and a legal street address. 
(8)  The names of the employees for the proposed established, if known, or, if presently unknown or there will be no employees, a statement to that effect. 
(9)  The applicant's current mailing address, current residential address, and current residential telephone number. 
(10)  A site plan of the proposed or existing establishment. A professionally prepared diagram in the nature of an engineer's or architect's blueprint shall not be required; however each site plan should be oriented to the north or to some designated street or object and should be drawn to a designated scale or with marked dimensions sufficient to show the various internal dimensions of all areas of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six inches. The site plan shall include but not be limited to the following: 
a.  All property lines, rights-of-way, and the location of buildings, parking areas and spaces, curb cuts, and driveways. 
b.  All windows, doors, entrances and exits, fixed structural features, walls, stairs, partitions, projection booths, admission booths, adult booths, concession booths, stands, food service equipment, counters and similar structures. 
c.  All proposed improvements or enlargements to be made, which shall be indicated and calculated in terms of percentage of increase in floor size. 
d.  Designation of any portion of the premises in which patrons will not be permitted. 
e.  A statement as to whether a proposed establishment is constructed in a manner that varies from the site plan submitted. A supplemental site plan, showing the existing facility, shall be provided once the certificate of occupancy or final building permit inspection is completed. 
(11)  A recent photograph of the individuals listed pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section. 
(12)  Either the driver's license number or the state or federally issued identification card number of the individuals listed pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section. 
(13)  A valid adult use permit signed by the director of planning and development or his designee pursuant to this article. 
(14)  A sworn statement attesting to the accuracy of the information provided in the application and to the fact that the applicant, as licensee, will own, possess, operate and exercise control over the proposed or existing adult use establishment. 
(c)  Application fee. 
(1)  The applicant for any adult use establishment shall pay, to the department of planning and development and prior to the application for a license, a fee in an amount to cover the expenses of the zoning review necessary to obtain an adult use permit pursuant to sections 10-226 and 10-22810-232 and division 3 of this article. The amount of the fee shall be established by resolution of the city commission and is listed in appendix A to this Code. Such fee shall be paid only one time for any proposed adult use location unless the proposal is to expand the dimensions of a permitted adult use. 
(2)  In addition to the zoning review fee required in subsection (c)(1) of this section, each application for an adult use license shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee in an amount established by resolution of the city commission and listed in appendix A to this Code. The fee is required to offset the cost of processing the application. If the application for a license is approved and a license is granted, the fee shall be applied as a credit toward the annual license fee required for the first year pursuant to section 10-193. 
(d)  Incomplete application. If the department of planning and development determines at any time that the applicant has not properly completed the application for a proposed establishment, the department of planning and development shall promptly notify the applicant of such fact and shall allow the applicant ten days to properly complete the application. The time period for granting or denying a license under section 10-190 shall be stayed during the period in which the applicant is allowed an opportunity to properly complete the application. 
(Code 1983, § 25-43; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-188. - False statement or false information. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any person applying for an adult use license to make a false statement which is intended to facilitate the issuance of a license or to provide false information which is intended to facilitate the issuance of a license. 
(Code 1983, § 25-93; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-189. - Investigation of applicant. 
Upon receipt of an application under this division properly filed with the department of planning and development and upon payment of the nonrefundable application fee, the department of planning and development shall immediately stamp the application as received and shall immediately thereafter send photocopies of the application to the chief of police. The police chief's representatives shall promptly conduct an investigation of the applicant, and of the individuals listed in the application pursuant to subsection 10-187(b) to ascertain the validity of the information provided in the application. At the conclusion of its investigation, the police department shall indicate, on the photocopy of the application, the results of its investigation. A copy of the application shall also be forwarded to the director of planning and development, who shall determine whether the plan for the licensed premises complies with the requirements of this Code and other applicable laws and regulations relating to construction, safety, fire protection, zoning and public health. 
(Code 1983, § 25-44; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-190. - Issuance; denial. 
(a)  Time limits. Under this division, the department of planning and development shall grant or deny an application for a license within 45 days from the date of its proper filing. Upon the expiration of the 45th day, the applicant shall be permitted to begin operating the establishment for which a license is sought, without benefit of a license, unless and until the department of planning and development notifies the applicant of a denial of the application and states the reason for that denial. Failure to timely grant or deny an application for a license under this section allowing operation without benefit of a license shall not serve as a granting of a license, but shall serve to ripen an appropriate action to compel a decision on the application. All operations of the establishments authorized under this special provision shall conform to sections 10-33, 10-6710-70 and 10-22610-232 and division 3 of this article during the pendency of the application review. 
(b)  Issuance. If there is no basis for denial, pursuant to subsection (c) of this section, the department of planning and development shall grant the application, notify the applicant of the granting, and issue the license to the applicant upon payment of the appropriate annual license fee provided in section 10-193, with credit as provided in section 10-187(c). 
(c)  Denial. The department of planning and development shall deny the application for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The application contains material false information or information material to the decision was omitted. Failure to list an individual required to be listed pursuant to subsection 10-187(b) and whose listing would result in a denial pursuant to subsections (c)(2) and (4) of this section is presumed to be a material false information for purposes of denial of the application. The certification that the licensee owns, possesses, operates and exercises control over the proposed or existing adult use establishment is a material representation for purposes of this section. 
(2)  The applicant or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to subsection 10-187(b)(1) holds or has held a license under this article or any other ordinance regulating adult uses in the city that has been suspended or revoked for reasons implicating the purposes and intent of this article. 
(3)  The granting of the application would violate a state or federal statute or city or applicable county ordinance or an order from a court of law. 
(4)  An applicant or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to subsection 10-187(b)(1) has been convicted of a specified criminal act: 
a.  For which: 
1.  Less that two years has elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a misdemeanor offense; 
2.  Less that five years has elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a felony offense; or 
3.  Less than five years has elapsed since the date of the last conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the convictions are of two or more misdemeanor offenses or combination of misdemeanor offenses occurring within any 24-month period. 
b.  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the disqualification of the applicant, except that if a conviction is overturned this shall be treated as if there were no such conviction. 
c.  An applicant who has been convicted of a specified criminal act may seek to qualify for an adult use license only when the time period required by subsection (c)(4) of this section has elapsed. 
(5)  If the department of planning and development denies the application, the applicant shall be notified of the denial, and the reason for the denial shall be specified upon the application or in a separate writing. Notification shall be by certified mail and shall be sent to the address on the license application, which shall be considered the correct address for all notices. 
(6)  If a person applies for a license at a particular location within a period of six months from the date of denial of a previous application for a license at that location and there has not been an intervening change in the circumstances material to the decision regarding the former reason for denial, the application shall not be accepted for consideration. The burden of showing an intervening change of circumstances shall be on the applicant. 
(7)  The granting of a license does not act as a certification that the proposed adult use establishment meets all sections of this article or of any health or zoning statute, code, ordinance, or regulation. The adult use establishment and any proposed adult use establishment, once established, must meet all Code provisions required of all regulated businesses, including the provisions for adult uses of sections 10-226 and 10-22810-232 and division 3 of this article. 
(8)  Within 15 days after the mailing of a notice of denial of an application for a license or a notification of the revocation of a license, the applicant or licensee may take an appeal as provided in section 10-199. If the administrative hearing officer finds that the application should be approved, he shall so order and, upon payment of the appropriate license fee, the director of planning and development shall issue the license. If the administrative hearing officer finds that the license should not have been revoked, he shall notify the director of planning and development, who shall reissue the license. 
(Code 1983, § 25-45; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-191. - Contents; limitations; term; renewal, expiration; cancellation. 
(a)  Contents. An adult use license shall state on its face the name of the licensee, the name of the establishment, the street address of the establishment, the classification of the license, the date of issuance, and the date of expiration. 
(b)  Limitations. No more than one license shall be issued and in effect for any single location within the city. A licensed premises may be owned by the licensee or may be leased by the licensee from a person not a licensee under this article, provided that a licensee who is a tenant or lessee shall not surrender his tenancy or lease to the owner or lessor if by doing so the owner or lessor will take possession, control and operation of the licensed premises and the business licensed under this article, unless the license is transferred as provided in section 10-195. A licensee who is the owner of the licensed premises shall not lease or otherwise give up possession, control and operation of the licensed premises and the business licensed under this article to any other individual, partnership or corporation, unless the license is transferred as provided in section 10-195. 
(c)  Term. Every license issued under this division shall be an annual license, which shall commence running on October 1, on which date they shall have been paid for, and shall expire on September 30 of the following year. If a license is issued after October 1 but by March 31 of the following year, the applicant may obtain a new license upon application therefor and the payment of the appropriate license fee, and such license shall expire on the following September 30. If a license is issued after March 31 but by October 1 of the same year, the applicant shall pay one-half the appropriate license fee required for the annual license, and such license shall expire on September 30 of the same year. This subsection shall not affect section 10-195. 
(d)  Renewals. All licenses issued under this division shall be renewed annually. Subject to other sections of this Code, a licensee under this article shall be entitled to a renewal of his annual license from year to year, as a matter of course, by October 1 by presenting the license for the previous year or satisfactory evidence of its loss or destruction to the director of planning and development and by paying the appropriate license fee and updating the information supplied with the latest application or certifying that the information supplied remains unchanged. 
(e)  Expiration. A license that is not renewed under this article on or before October 1 of each year shall expire. 
(f)  Cancellation. All expired licenses not renewed on or before October 1 shall be cancelled summarily by the department of planning and development, unless such license is involved in litigation and the city is legally prevented from cancelling it by order or a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1983, § 25-46; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-192. - Alteration. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any person to alter or otherwise change the contents of an adult use license without the written permission of the department of planning and development. 
(Code 1983, § 25-92; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-193. - Annual regulatory fees. 
(a)  Levied. In order to cover the administrative and enforcement costs associated with this article, there are levied annual licensing regulatory fees under this article for an adult entertainment establishment in amounts set by resolution of the city commission and listed in appendix A to this Code. Such fees shall be charged for each establishment proposing to operate or operating only as: 
(1)  An adult theater, which shall pay licensing regulatory fees for the following: 
a.  Having only adult booths, a fee for each booth; 
b.  Having only a hall or auditorium, for each seat; 
c.  Having only an area outdoors designed to permit viewing by customers seated in vehicles, for each parking space; or 
d.  Having a combination of two or more of the items listed in subsections (a)(1)a(1)c of this section, the cumulative license fee applicable to each under subsections (a)(1)a(1)c of this section. 
(2)  A special adult cabaret. 
(3)  An adult photographic studio. 
(4)  A physical culture establishment. 
(5)  An adult bookstore/video store. 
(6)  An adult use which cannot be categorized according to the categories in subsections (a)(1) through (5) of this section shall be assessed at the rate applicable to the adult use most closely resembling the proposed or existing use. 
(b)  Purpose. The annual license fees collected under this section are declared to be regulatory fees which are collected for the purpose of examination and inspection of adult uses under this article and the administration thereof. These regulatory fees are in addition to and not in lieu of the occupational license taxes, building permit, zoning, food establishment fees, or other fees imposed by other sections of this Code. 
(Code 1983, § 25-47; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-194. - Records and reports; consent by licensee. 
(a)  Records and reports. Each licensee under this division shall keep such records and make such reports as are required under this article. Whenever the information required by or provided under subsection 10-187(b)(1) has changed, the licensee shall promptly provide the department of planning and development with the changed information. 
(b)  Consent. By holding a license under this article, the licensee shall be deemed to have consented to the requirements of this article and to the exercise by the department of planning and development and other departments of their respective responsibilities under this article. 
(Code 1983, § 25-48; Ord. No. 94-51, § 2, 11-15-94)  
Sec. 10-195. - Transferability. 
(a)  Requirements. A licensee under this division shall not transfer his license to another business entity or person and thereby surrender ownership, possession, control, and operation of the licensed establishment to such other business entity or person, unless and until such other business entity or person satisfies the following requirements:
