(c)  COLA. Members accruing benefits under this section shall not be entitled to a cost of living adjustment, except as provided for in subsection 66-326(e). 
(d)  Vesting. If a member terminates employment, either voluntarily or by lawful discharge, the member shall be entitled to the following: 
(1)  With less than ten years of credited service (including credited service earned prior to January 1, 2013), a member is entitled to a refund of member contributions without interest. 
(2)  With ten or more years of credited service (including credited service earned prior to January 1, 2013) a member is entitled to either: 
a.  The pension benefit accrued to the member's date of termination, based on the terms of the plan in effect on such date of termination, payable commencing at the member's otherwise normal retirement date, provided the member does not elect to withdraw his or her member contributions; or 
b.  Refund of member contributions without interest. 
(e)  DROP. No member may enter the DROP on or after January 1, 2013. Members already participating in DROP on January 1, 2013 may complete their DROP participation. Provided, members who are employed on December 31, 2012 and have attained age 55 or 25 years of credited service on that date shall be eligible to enter and participate in the DROP on or after January 1, 2013. 
(Ord. No. 12-24, § 7, 12-27-12; Ord. No. 2017-16, § 10, 10-10-17)  
Sec. 66-339.1. - Supplemental benefit component for special benefits; chapter 175 share accounts. 
There is hereby established an additional plan component to provide special benefits in the form of a supplemental retirement, termination, death and disability benefits to be in addition to the benefits provided for in the previous sections of this plan, such benefit to be funded solely and entirely by F.S. ch. 175, premium tax monies for each plan year which are allocated to this supplemental component as provided for in F.S. § 175.351. Amounts allocated to this supplemental component ("share plan") shall be further allocated to the members and DROP participants in a manner to be agreed upon. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16, § 11, 10-10-17)  
Sec. 66-339.2. - Reemployment after retirement. 
(a)  Any retiree under this system may be reemployed by any public or private employer and may receive compensation from that employment without limiting or restricting in any way the retirement benefits payable under this system. Notwithstanding the previous sentence, reemployment by the city shall be subject to the limitations set forth in this section. 
(b)  After normal retirement. Any retiree who is retired under normal retirement pursuant to this system and who is reemployed as a firefighter and, by virtue of that reemployment, is eligible to participate in this system, shall upon being reemployed, discontinue receipt of benefits. Upon reemployment, the member shall be deemed to be fully vested and the additional credited service accrued during the subsequent employment period shall be used in computing a second benefit amount attributable to the subsequent employment period, which benefit amount shall be added to the benefit determined upon the initial retirement to determine the total benefit payable upon final retirement. Calculations of benefits upon retirement shall be based upon the benefit accrual rate, average final compensation, and credited service as of that date and the retirement benefit amount for any subsequent employment period shall be based upon the benefit accrual rate, average final compensation (based only on the subsequent employment period and not including any period of DROP participation), and credited service as of the date of subsequent retirement. The amount of any death or disability benefit received during a subsequent period of employment shall be reduced by the amount of accrued benefit eligible to be paid for a prior period of employment. The optional form of benefit and any joint pensioner selected upon initial retirement shall not be subject to change upon subsequent retirement except as otherwise provided herein, but the retiree may select a different optional form and joint pensioner applicable only to the subsequent retirement benefit. 
(c)  Any retiree who is retired under normal retirement pursuant to this system who is reemployed by the city in a position other than as a firefighter, shall upon being reemployed, continue receipt of benefits for the period of any subsequent employment period. Former DROP participants shall begin receipt of benefits under these circumstances. 
(d)  After early retirement. Any retiree who is retired under early retirement pursuant to this system and who subsequently becomes an employee of the city in any capacity shall discontinue receipt of benefits from the system. If the reemployed person, by virtue of his reemployment, is eligible to participate in this system, that person shall accrue a second benefit as provided for in subsection (2) above and benefit payments shall remain suspended during any such subsequent employment period. If the reemployed person is not eligible to participate in this system, that person's pension benefit payments shall be suspended until the earlier of termination of employment or such time as the reemployed retiree reaches the date that he would have been eligible for normal retirement under this system had he continued employment and not elected early retirement. "Normal retirement" as used in this subsection shall be the current normal retirement date provided for under this system. 
(e)  After disability retirement. 
(1)  Subject to paragraph (2) below, any retiree who is retired under section 66-328, Disability ("disability retiree"), may, subject to subsection (e), physical examination requirement, of that section, be reemployed by any public or private employer, and may receive compensation from that employment without limiting or restricting in any way, the retirement benefits payable under this system. 
(2)  Any disability retiree who subsequently becomes an employee of the city in any capacity, except as a firefighter, shall discontinue receipt of disability benefits from the system for the period of any such employment. 
(3)  If a disability retiree is reemployed as a firefighter for the city, his disability benefit shall cease and section 66-328, subsection (e) shall apply. 
(f)  Reemployment of terminated vested persons. Reemployed terminated vested persons shall not be subject to the provisions of this section until such time as they begin to actually receive benefits. Upon receipt of benefits, terminated vested persons shall be treated as normal or early retirees for purposes of applying the provisions of this section and their status as an early or normal retiree shall be determined by the date they elect to begin to receive their benefit. 
(g)  DROP Participants. Retirees who were in the deferred retirement option plan shall, following termination of employment after DROP participation, have the options provided for in this section for reemployment. 
(Ord. No. 19-11, § 5, 7-23-19)  
Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Distribution of handbills restricted, § 46-1; nuisances, § 46-31 et seq.; junked, wrecked and abandoned property, § 46-96 et seq.; utilities, ch. 86; concurrency management system, ch. 102. 
State Law reference Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166; Florida Litter Law of 1971, F.S. § 403.413. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 70-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Construction and demolition debris means, for purposes of this article, construction and demolition debris has the dame meaning as assigned to that term in Chapter 62-701.200(27) F.A.C. 
Dumpster means a garbage, trash or other waste material container that is mechanically lifted on to a refuse truck. The term "dumpster" shall include compactors and roll-offs. 
Garbage means refuse, tin cans, glass, paper, bottles and the boxes and paper coming from or being disposed of by residents and commercial or business establishments, and all refuse, kitchen accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter, liquid or other, that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables, and other refuse that may accumulate in the normal household, which shall all be contained in receptacles specifically provided for that purpose. The term shall also include all boxes and containers, provided such boxes and containers shall be broken down flat. 
Garbage can means a galvanized iron or other standard metal or plastic can and cover to fit, of the type commonly sold as a garbage can, of not less than five nor more than 20 gallons in capacity, or other acceptable container; such receptacle to have two handles upon the sides thereof or a suitable bale by which it may be readily lifted for the purposes of easily emptying the can in a garbage pickup truck; and the metal cover of which shall be tightfitting and kept in place on the can for the purpose of preventing stenches or other nuisance. 
Multiple dwellings means all places of abode other than single-family residences such as apartment houses, roominghouses and boardinghouses, sanitariums, rest homes, hospitals, resident schools, hotels, motels and motor courts, guesthouses, tourist homes, trailer courts, trailer camps and all other similar places. 
Noncombustible refuse or words of similar connotation mean refuse materials that are unburnable at ordinary bonfire or incinerator temperatures, such as durable junk, metals, mineral matter, stone, cement and concrete derivatives, glass, crockery, metal furniture, or parts thereof, vehicle bodies or parts thereof, and other similar material or refuse, none of which shall be placed in garbage containers or in any way mixed with garbage. 
Temporary construction roll-off container means a dumpster used on a temporary construction site or a special event. 
Trash means any refuse other than garbage or putrescible material. This shall include discarded paper, discarded flower decorations, cuttings of grass and weeds and branches and vines, provided such branches, shrubs and vines are placed in containers or bundles not to exceed 40 pounds in weight or four feet in length. The term "trash" does not include earth, trees, tree trunks, limbs over three inches in diameter, wallpaper, roofing material, plaster, concrete, or other substances that may accumulate as a result of repairs to land or buildings or as a result of initial clearing of lots or as a result of building operations. For practical purposes, unless otherwise prohibited and where not unduly cumbersome for ordinary pickup and disposal purposes, trash may include noncombustible as well as combustible refuse, unless and until trash shall be disposed of by incinerator method. 
(Code 1960, § 10-1; Ord. No. 25, §§ 36, 8; Code 1983, § 9-1; Ord. No. 91-1, § 1, 2-5-91; Ord. No. 08-17, § 1, 5-13-08) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-2. - Treatment of garbage matter specified. 
(a)  All garbage, tin cans, bottles and other disposable containers shall first be drained of liquids and shall be deposited at least once daily in garbage cans required in section 70-36. 
(b)  The wet garbage matter shall be drained and wrapped in paper before being placed in a garbage can; provided, however, hotels, restaurants or other eating establishments, upon an exemption granted by the city, shall not be required to wrap wet garbage and provided, further, all such excepted persons shall clean and rinse and maintain in a reasonably sanitary and nonodorous condition each garbage can immediately following each collection of garbage and shall at all times maintain the can free from stench or other nuisance, which shall be done in such way as not to commit a public or private nuisance. 
(Code 1960, § 10-6; Ord. No. 25, § 10; Code 1983, § 9-5)  
Sec. 70-3. - Accumulation of garbage and insufficient number of cans. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant or manager or person responsible for any land or premises to permit, suffer or allow, either by commission or omission, any accumulation of garbage or other waste material upon premises or property within the city for a period longer than four days, without having arranged for disposal of the accumulation by some person qualified under this chapter to perform such services or by the duly authorized garbage collector of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person, whether owner, manager or occupant of any premises, to fail to provide a sufficient number of containers per unit as provided in this chapter to amply provide for any four-day period of garbage or other noxious wastes. 
(Code 1960, § 10-7; Ord. No. 25, § 30; Code 1983, § 9-6)  
Sec. 70-4. - Removal of industrial waste by owner. 
Industrial wastes and other noncombustible refuse must be removed by the owner, occupant or operator or by a duly licensed contractor at the user's expense. 
(Code 1960, § 10-8; Ord. No. 25, § 28; Code 1983, § 9-7)  
Sec. 70-5. - Burning. 
No garbage, refuse, trash or other discarded matter shall be burned in an incinerator, furnace or other similar incinerating device or directly upon real property within the corporate limits. 
(Code 1960, § 10-9; Ord. No. 25, § 16; Ord. No. 115, § 1; Code 1983, § 9-8)  
Sec. 70-6. - Burial. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bury garbage, trash or any other unwholesome matter. 
(Code 1960, § 10-10; Ord. No. 25, § 15; Code 1983, § 9-9)  
Sec. 70-7. - Transportation of garbage. 
Unless specifically authorized by resolution of the city commission, it shall be unlawful for any person to transport garbage through or over the public streets or alleys, except for the purpose of having the garbage picked up by persons authorized by the city to pick up and dispose of the garbage. 
(Code 1960, § 10-11; Ord. No. 25, § 17; Code 1983, § 9-10)  
Sec. 70-8. - Littering; placement in cans of another. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit garbage, refuse, trash or other discarded matter upon the premises of another or upon any street, alley, parkway, or other public or private property or into any drain, canal, ditch, waterway, gulf, bay, rockbed, sandbed, pool, pond, or the like within the city or in the can or receptacle of another who has paid the collection service fee as provided in this chapter. However, tenants of multiple dwellings or businesses where authorized may deposit garbage in cans which shall be authorized for the use of such tenants by the owner or manager thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 10-12; Ord. No. 127, § 1; Ord. No. 250, § 1; Code 1983, § 9-11)  
Sec. 70-9. - Prevention of accumulations. 
In order to prevent any overflow of garbage, trash, noncombustible refuse or any other waste material, the city shall be entitled to require that either the size of the garbage can or dumpster be increased or that pickup service be increased or both, at the expense of the property owner or property occupant. 
(Code 1983, § 9-12; Ord. No. 91-1, § 5, 2-5-91)  
Secs. 70-1070-35. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONTAINERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference Garbage cans and dumpsters, § 134-1296 et seq. 
 
Sec. 70-36. - Required; exemptions; covers; placement for collection. 
(a)  All owners or residents or occupants of single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, multiple-family dwellings, businesses, and commercial establishments or enterprises within the city shall provide either garbage cans or dumpsters of sufficient capacity to hold garbage and trash which has accumulated between service pickup days. 
(b)  Each cooking unit of a single-family dwelling, two-family dwelling or a multiple-family dwelling shall have either garbage cans or dumpsters adequate and sufficient in size to hold garbage, trash, noncombustible refuse and other waste materials which have accumulated between service pickup days as provided in subsection (a) of this section. Garbage cans and dumpsters, whether for residential dwellings, two-family dwellings, multiple-family dwellings, businesses or commercial enterprises or establishments, shall be placed in one location on the premises for collection purposes, which location shall be approved by the city. 
(c)  Garbage cans and dumpsters shall be kept tightly covered at all times, except when it is necessary to lift the cover for disposal or removal of garbage, trash, noncombustible refuse or other waste materials or to deposit such therein. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit garbage, trash, noncombustible refuse or other waste materials in such amounts in the can or dumpster that will not permit the cover to be kept tightly in place. Temporary construction roll-off containers shall be exempt from the requirements of this subsection, but shall be required to comply with all other requirements of this chapter. 
(d)  Residential garbage can customers may not deposit cans at the curb other than the night before their scheduled pickup and the cans must be removed by nightfall the same day of the scheduled pickup. 
(e)  Dumpster screening gates shall be open in a position suitable for pickup of front loader service. 
(f)  Horticultural trimmings placed at curbside in accordance with other city ordinances and regulations shall be exempt from this section. 
(Code 1960, §§ 10-2, 10-3; Ord. No. 25, §§ 9, 11; Code 1983, § 9-2; Ord. No. 91-1, § 2, 2-5-91)  
Sec. 70-37. - Sanitation. 
Garbage cans and dumpsters shall be kept aboveground in places easily accessible to the city inspector and to the employees of the garbage collector. Garbage cans and dumpsters shall not be kept in such places or under such conditions as to cause an unnecessary or unreasonable offense to sightliness, cleanliness, safety or other sanitary conditions. Garbage cans shall not be kept upon neighboring property not in ownership or tenancy of the person by whom the garbage was accumulated, whether such neighboring property is vacant or improved, without the written consent of the person having the right to grant such consent. This section is subject to the regulations contained in section 134-1296 et seq. 
(Code 1960, § 10-4; Ord. No. 25, § 12; Code 1983, § 9-3; Ord. No. 91-1, § 3, 2-5-91)  
Sec. 70-38. - Inspection; condemnation. 
All garbage cans and dumpsters shall be subject to an inspection and approval or condemnation by the city inspector or police department at all times. Upon condemnation by the city inspector or police of any garbage can or dumpster, a notice of such condemnation shall be placed upon the condemned can or handed to the owner or occupant or left at his regular place of abode, and he shall comply therewith. It shall be unlawful for any person to place in such condemned can or dumpster any garbage or other material, and the owner or occupant of the premises shall forthwith provide a new can or dumpster to take the place of the can or dumpster condemned. 
(Code 1960, § 10-5; Ord. No. 25, § 13; Code 1983, § 9-4; Ord. No. 91-1, § 4, 2-5-91)  
Sec. 70-39. - Construction and demolition debris collection. 
All temporary construction roll off containers for sites within the city that contain construction and demolition debris shall be provided by a construction and demolition debris collection and/or recycling provider authorized by the city. 
(Ord. No. 08-17, § 2, 5-13-08)  
Secs. 70-4070-65. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - COLLECTION SERVICE[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference Florida Resources Recovery and Management Act, F.S. § 403.701 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 70-66. - City to provide; use required. 
(a)  The city shall provide garbage and trash collection services reasonably adequate and sufficient to take care of the reasonable disposal needs of all properties within the city limits, either by establishing and operating its own garbage and trash collection and disposal facilities or by contracting or subcontracting with a private contractor. 
(b)  All residents, occupants or owners of premises in the city are required to have all accumulations of garbage removed and disposed of by such garbage collection services. 
(Code 1960, § 10-23; Ord. No. 25, §§ 23(a), 25(b); Code 1983, § 9-26; Ord. No. 95-58, § 1, 1-3-96)  
Sec. 70-67. - City manager's duties. 
The office of the city manager shall do whatsoever is necessary and proper in the organization, operation, billing, collections and all other things incident to the garbage and trash collection and disposal services. 
(Code 1960, § 10-36; Ord. No. 25, § 23(i); Ord. No. 412, § 30; Ord. No. 418, § 8; Code 1983, § 9-28)  
Sec. 70-68. - Collection schedule for transient users. 
Other special, temporary or transient users of the solid waste collection system, such as circuses, tent shows, carnivals or other miscellaneous or transient users, shall pay such fee for garbage and trash collection services as determined by the city commission either by ordinance or franchise agreement. 
(Code 1960, § 10-28; Ord. No. 25, § 25(k); Code 1983, § 9-27)  
Secs. 70-6970-95. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RATES AND CHARGES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note Rates are also provided for in a contract or agreement between the city and a private garbage collection company. 
 
Sec. 70-96. - Payment required. 
It is mandatory for all improved properties within the city, unless specifically exempted, to pay the prescribed fees and charges for garbage and trash collection service. The owner of each unit of improved real estate within the city and all persons utilizing garbage and trash collection services shall pay the fee for such collection services as billed. 
(Code 1960, §§ 10-31, 10-32; Ord. No. 25, § 25(b), (d); Ord. No. 418, § 6; Code 1983, § 9-41)  
Sec. 70-97. - Basis. 
(a)  Generally. The city shall determine from time to time the reasonable cost of garbage collection and disposal services and shall, by appropriate ordinance or franchise agreement, assess and impose a unit cost against the owner, user or occupant of every improved property within the city, which rate for the collection and disposal services furnished or available shall be equivalent and uniform according to a schedule of rate per unit or for other type of classified user having need for garbage and trash collection and disposal services. 
(b)  Overhead expenses. The city commission, in computing the charge per unit against the users of garbage and trash collection service, shall take into consideration the administrative and servicing charges incident to billing and collecting accounts, making payments to the garbage collector and any other incidental or legitimate charges as may be sufficient to pay for the entire garbage collection services. 
(c)  Type and amount of service. The charge for such services shall be based upon the type and amount of garbage and trash collections, the number of containers per week, and the frequency in schedule of collections, as the city commission shall from time to time determine and provide by ordinance or franchise agreement. Appropriate discounts for advance payment of the required service fees may be provided by appropriate ordinance. 
(Code 1960, §§ 10-29, 10-30; Ord. No. 25, §§ 24, 25(a), (c); Ord. No. 412, § 27; Ord. No. 418, § 5; Code 1983, § 9-42)  
Sec. 70-98. - Changes or modifications. 
(a)  Nothing shall prevent the city commission from time to time from modifying or changing the type or schedule of garbage and trash collection service, so long as reasonably adequate service is provided to take care of the minimum needs of the people of the city. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this chapter shall prevent the city commission from time to time, in the light of experience and in accordance with its contractual or other costs, including administrative and other incidental costs, to modify the charge per unit for garbage and trash collection services rendered by the city for the people of the city, provided that such shall be done by ordinance or franchise agreement adopted by the city commission. 
(Code 1960, § 10-35; Ord. No. 25, § 25(f); Code 1983, § 9-43)  
Sec. 70-99. - Collection procedures and remedies. 
(a)  If a customer fails to pay the amount due to the city under this division, the city may enforce collection of the rate by imposing a lien on the real property involved, by filing a civil action against the customer for the amount due to the city, by ceasing further garbage and trash or refuse collection service or by all of such remedies. 
(b)  All property within the city is subject to lien for nonpayment of the garbage and trash collection service charges. In addition to any other penalties prescribed in this chapter, if the owner of any improved property subject to payment of collection service charges fails to pay such charges on or before the final date set by the city for payment or fails to pay charges in advance when the service is commenced during the year, the city may impose a lien upon the property of such owner. The amount of such lien shall be based upon the total service charge due, plus eight percent interest, plus all costs, including reasonable attorney's fee, incident to filing and imposing the lien. Such lien shall be imposed against the land and may be enforced and the property sold to satisfy such lien in the manner prescribed by law. 
(c)  In addition to any other penalty prescribed by this chapter, if the owner of any improved property subject to payment of garbage and trash charges fails to pay the amount due within 60 days from the original date of billing, the city shall assess a penalty equivalent to one percent a month on the unpaid bill, plus $5.00. 
(Code 1960, §§ 10-30.1(d), 10-33; Ord. No. 25, § 34; Ord. No. 376, § 1; Ord. No. 80-40, §§ 112; Ord. No. 81-25, § 1; Ord. No. 81-46, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 82-1, § 1; Code 1983, § 9-45) 
State Law reference Enforcement of statutory liens, F.S. ch. 85; foreclosure of municipal tax and special assessment liens, F.S. ch. 173.  
Secs. 70-10070-125. - Reserved.

ARTICLE II. - OBSTRUCTIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 74-31. - Unlawful conduct. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to in any way obstruct the streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public passageways of the city except as authorized by the building code, as adopted in section 98-26 and amended by the city, or by ordinance; provided, however, that alleyways in Pass-a-Grille south of 32nd Avenue that have a platted width of 15 feet or greater may have planted landscaping that reduces the width of the clear travel path to no less than 12 feet, with equal portions of landscaping on each side of the alley, with an approved right-of-way use permit issued by the city manager. Such landscaping shall not block access to any driveway and shall not reduce the visibility triangles required by division 6 of the land development regulations. The city reserves the right to trim or remove any such landscaping at its discretion, with or without notice, for any reason related to the health, safety or welfare of the community without compensation to any adjacent property owner. 
(Code 1960, § 16-17; Code 1983, § 19-16; Ord. No. 09-20, § 1, 9-21-09)  
Sec. 74-32. - Goods, boxes, benches along sidewalks and streets; permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or the agent or representative of any person to place, put or leave any goods, wares, merchandise, boxes, benches or other obstructions of any nature whatsoever on any of the sidewalks along the streets of the city outside the property line of the streets. 
(b)  Benches or seats for occupancy by persons may be placed and maintained on and along the sidewalks, provided they are maintained by the owner or occupant of the abutting property in a safe and sightly condition and no part thereof extends more than 24 inches outside of and beyond the property line of such owner. 
(c)  Goods and merchandise delivered to duly licensed merchants and operators of places of business may be deposited and left on the sidewalks immediately in front of the places of business of such merchants and operators between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m. of the next morning, if any such place of business is not then open or has no storage area to receive such goods and merchandise at time of delivery. The leaving of any goods or merchandise on the sidewalks after 8:00 a.m. of the morning of delivery shall be and constitute a violation of this section by the merchant or operator of the place of business to whom such delivery is made. 
(d)  Any person may apply to the city manager for a permit which would allow an exemption from this section. The application shall be made in sufficient time to enable the city manager to investigate such facts as he deems appropriate in order to reach a determination as to whether or not to issue the requested permit. The permit shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  The city manager may attach such conditions to the permit as deemed appropriate, and the permit holder shall comply with all such conditions. 
(2)  Any permit issued by the city manager shall only be valid for the date, time or place specifically set forth in the permit. 
(3)  The issuance of a permit shall be within the discretion of the city manager, and the granting of a permit in one instance shall not be construed as precedence for the issuance of any other permit, even if such conditions are identical to those for which a permit has previously been issued. 
(4)  The city manager may, without notice, terminate a permit if the holder thereof does not comply with any of the conditions of such permit or if the holder thereof is in violation of any of the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1960, § 16-18; Ord. No. 335, § 1; Code 1983, § 19-17; Ord. No. 85-6, § 1, 3-5-85)  
Sec. 74-33. - Sidewalk sale permits. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any of the sections of this chapter, the city manager shall have authority to issue a permit which would allow the holder thereof to conduct a sidewalk sale under the terms and conditions set forth in the permit. 
(b)  The procedure for the application for the granting of the permit shall be as follows: 
(1)  The applicant shall notify the city manager or his designee, in writing, of his intent to apply for a permit granting a sidewalk sale. 
(2)  The applicant shall submit to the city manager such information as the city manager deems appropriate in order to assist him in making a decision as to whether or not to grant or deny the application. 
(c)  If the application has been granted, a written permit shall be issued. The permit may be in any form determined appropriate by the city manager. 
(d)  Permits for sidewalk sales, when issued by the city manager, shall only be valid for the date and time and place specifically set forth in the permit. The issuance of a permit for a sidewalk sale shall be within the discretion of the city manager, and the granting of a permit in one instance shall not be construed as precedence for the granting of a permit in any other instance. 
(Code 1983, § 19-18; Ord. No. 85-6, § 2, 3-5-85) 
Cross reference Special event permits, § 26-31 et seq.  
Secs. 74-3474-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - NEWSPAPER RACKS 
 
Sec. 74-61. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alley means a minor right-of-way providing secondary vehicular access to the side or rear of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
Distributor means the person or any other legal entity owning or responsible for placing or maintaining a newspaper box or vending machine in a public right-of-way. 
Newspaper rack means any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit, vending machine or other dispenser installed, used or maintained for the display, sale or distribution of newspapers or other news periodicals or advertising circulars. The term "newspaper rack" shall include the term "newspaper box" or "newspaper vending machine." 
Public property means any park, cemetery, school yard, open space adjacent thereto, all waterways and sovereign lands as designated by the state or the United States government or the city. 
Recovery area means that space as determined by the state department of transportation specifications which is measured from the edge of the roadway outward and which is required to clear of fixed objects. 
Right-of-way means all lands conveyed or dedicated to the public to be used for a street, alley, walkway, drainage facility or other public purpose. 
Roadway means that portion of a street unimproved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, including a median. 
Street means that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, including a median. 
Walkway means a right-of-way intended primarily for use by pedestrians, including self-propelled vehicles. 
(Code 1983, § 19-19(b); Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 5-18-93) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2; businesses, ch. 26.  
Sec. 74-62. - Purpose and criteria. 
The purpose and criteria of the following is to promote the public health, safety and welfare through regulation of location, installation, appearance and servicing of newspaper racks on public rights-of-way so as to: 
(1)  Provide for pedestrian, handicap and driving safety and convenience. 
(2)  Provide for free and unobstructed passage along the sidewalks of the city. 
(3)  Restrict unreasonable interference with the flow of pedestrians, including disabled persons, or vehicular traffic, including ingress or egress from any residence or place of business or from the street to the sidewalk, by persons exiting or entering parked or standing vehicles. 
(4)  Reduce unnecessary exposure of the public to personal injury or property damage. 
(5)  Provide for public and property safety during high winds associated with storms and hurricane conditions. 
(6)  Provide reasonable access for the use and maintenance of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes, and access to locations used for public transportation purposes. 
(7)  Relocate and replace newspaper racks which result in a visual blight and excessive space allocation on the public right-of-way or which detract from the aesthetics of the character of the neighborhood. 
(8)  Treat all newspapers equally, regardless of size, content, circulation, or frequency of publication. 
(9)  Maintain and preserve freedom of the press. 
(10)  Cooperate to the maximum with newspaper distributors. 
(Code 1983, § 19-19(a); Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 5-18-93)  
Sec. 74-63. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Upon determination by the director of community services or his designee that a newspaper rack has been installed, used or maintained in violation of this division, an order to correct the offending conditions shall be issued to the distributor of the newspaper rack. Such order shall be mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested to the address required by subsection 74-64(a). The order shall specifically describe the offending condition, suggest action necessary to correct the condition and advise of removal pursuant to subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Failure to promptly correct the offending condition within ten days after receipt of the order shall result in the offending newspaper rack being removed by the city. When the distributor of the offending newspaper rack is not known or identified as required by this section, a copy of the order shall be posted on the newspaper rack, and this shall be deemed sufficient notice. 
(c)  Any distributor aggrieved by a decision to remove or by the removal of a newspaper rack shall, upon written request, be entitled to a hearing before the city manager or his designee, at which time the distributor may show why the newspaper rack complies with this division or why compliance should not be required. If the distributor appeals the order to the city manager or his designee, removal of the newspaper rack shall be stayed pending final disposition of the appeal. 
(d)  Any newspaper rack removed from the public right-of-way shall be stored at the cost of the distributor. The city shall be reimbursed by the distributor for all costs incurred in the removal and storage of all newspaper racks removed from the public right-of-way by the city. Within three days after the removal of any newspaper rack from the public right-of-way, the city shall send the distributor of the newspaper rack, by certified mail, return receipt requested, notice of removal. The city is authorized to sell the newspaper rack at a public sale if the newspaper rack is not claimed by the distributor within a period of 60 days from the date of removal. Seven days prior to sale, the city shall advertise notice of the sale in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the city. All unpaid removal and storage costs and advertisement costs shall be paid out of the proceeds of the sale of the newspaper racks. The remaining balance of the sale proceeds shall become the property of the city and shall be transferred to the city's general fund. 
(Code 1983, § 19-19(f); Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 5-18-93)  
Sec. 74-64. - Identification and registration. 
(a)  Each newspaper rack shall have affixed to it in a readily visible place the telephone number of a working telephone service to call to report a malfunction or to secure a refund if the coin-return mechanism malfunctions and shall also provide the name and address of the distributor to receive the notices provided for in this division. 
(b)  Although no permit or license is required prior to the placement of newspaper racks, any person who places or maintains such a newspaper rack shall notify the director or community services or his designee of the location or of a change in location. 
(Code 1983, § 19-19(d); Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 5-18-93)  
Sec. 74-65. - Standards. 
All newspaper racks maintained or operated within a public right-of-way or other public property shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  No newspaper rack shall be placed on a roadway. Newspaper racks shall be placed on that portion of the sidewalk farthest away from the edge of a street or curb, in conformance with subsection (10) of this and other applicable sections of this division. 
(2)  No newspaper rack shall be allowed at any location whereby the clear space for the passage of pedestrians, persons in handicap devices or bicycle riders is reduced to less than five feet, pursuant to subsection (10)f of this section. 
(3)  No newspaper rack shall be placed at any site or location when the installation, use or maintenance: 
a.  Endangers the safety of persons or property; 
b.  Unreasonably interferes with or impedes the flow of pedestrians, persons in handicap or disabled person devices or vehicular traffic, including any legally parked or stopped vehicle; or 
c.  Unreasonably interferes with the use of traffic signs or signals, hydrants or mailboxes permitted at or near the location. 
(4)  No newspaper rack shall exceed 36 inches in height, 30 inches in width or 20 inches in depth. 
(5)  No newspaper rack shall be chained, bolted or otherwise attached to any property or to any permanently fixed object not owned by the distributor of the newspaper rack businessRequired. 
No persons shall engage in or carry out the business of massage unless he has a valid massage business permit issued by the city pursuant to the provisions of this chapter for each and every separate office or place of business conducted by such person. 
(Code 1988, ch. 4, § 8.03; Ord. No. 1982-16, § 2a, 8-19-1982)  
Sec. 22-26. - SameApplication. 
Any person desiring a massage business permit shall file a written application with the chief of police and city secretary on a form to be furnished by the city secretary. The applicant shall accompany the application with a tender of the correct permit fee as hereinafter provided and shall, in addition, furnish the following:

(4)  A complete list of the names and residence addresses of all masseurs and employees in the business and the name and residence addresses of the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business;

a.  Name, complete residence address and telephone numbers; 
b.  The two previous addresses immediately prior to the present address of the applicant; 
c.  Written proof of age;

e.  Two front-face portrait photographs taken within 30 days of the date of the application and at least two inches by two inches in size; 
f.  The massage or similar business history and experience ten years prior to the date of application, including, but not limited to, whether or not such person previously operating in this or another city or state under license or permit has had such license or permit denied, revoked, or suspended and the reason therefor, and the business activities or occupations subsequent to such action of denial, suspension or revocation; 
g.  All criminal arrests other than misdemeanor traffic violations, fully disclosing the jurisdiction in which arrested and the offense for which arrested and the disposition thereof; 
h.  A complete set of fingerprints taken and to be retained on file by the chief of police or his authorized representatives; 
(6)  Such other information, identification, and physical examination of the person as shall be deemed necessary by the police chief to discover the truth of the matters hereinbefore required to be set forth in the application; 
(7)  Authorization for the city, its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the permit; 
(8)  The names and addresses of three adult residents of the county who will serve as character references. These references must be persons other than relatives and business associates; 
(9)  Written declaration of the applicant, under penalty of perjury, that the foregoing information contained in the application is true and correct, said declaration being duly dated and signed in the city. 
(Code 1988, ch. 4, § 8.05; Ord. No. 1982-16, § 3, 8-19-1982)

Chapter 78 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Finance, § 2-186 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 78-1. - Additional homestead exemption for persons 65 and older. 
(a)  Any person who has the legal or equitable title to real estate and maintains thereon the permanent residence of the owner, who has attained the age of 65 years prior to January first of the year for which the exemption is sought, and whose household income does not exceed the amount stated in Section 196.075 Florida Statutes, shall be entitled to an additional homestead exemption of $25,000.00. 
(b)  The exemption granted by this ordinance applies only to ad valorem taxes levied by the city. 
(c)  Any person who claims an exemption under this ordinance shall submit to the county property appraiser, not later than March 1, a sworn statement of household income on a form prescribed by the department of revenue. 
(Ord. No. 00-01, § 1, 1-18-00; Ord. No. 01-33, § 1, 9-18-01; Ord. No. 02-20, § 1, 10-15-02; Ord. No. 07-04, § 1, 2-27-07)

ARTICLE II. - INSURANCE PREMIUM TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 26. 
 
Sec. 78-26. - Tax on property insurance for benefit of firefighters' pension trust fund. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "property insurance" shall have the meaning assigned to it by F.S. § 175.032. 
(b)  There is assessed, imposed and levied on every insurance company, corporation or other insurer engaged in or carrying on or who shall engage in or carry on the business of property insuring and every insurance company, corporation or other insurer engaging in or carrying on or which shall engage in or carry on the business of property insurance, as shown by the records of the state department of insurance, an excise or license tax, in addition to any license tax or excise tax levied by the city, in the amount of 1.85 percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policy holders on all premiums collected on property insurance policies with the corporate limits. 
(c)  The net proceeds of the tax assessed and collected pursuant to subsection (a) of this section shall be allocated to and used solely for the municipal firefighters' pension trust fund, pursuant to F.S. ch. 175. 
(Code 1960, § 20-8(a), (b); Ord. No. 29, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 193, §§ 2, 3; Code 1983, § 11-2) 
Cross reference Firefighters retirement system, § 66-251 et seq. 
State Law reference Tax on property insurance for benefit of firefighters' retirement fund authorized, F.S. § 175.101; property insurance authorized, F.S. § 175.032(4).  
Sec. 78-27. - Tax on casualty insurance for benefit of police officers' retirement trust fund. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "casualty insurance" shall have the meaning assigned to it by F.S. § 185.02. 
(b)  There is assessed, imposed and levied on every insurance company, corporation or other insurer engaged in or carrying on or who shall engage in or carry on the business of casualty insurance, as shown by the records of the state department of insurance, an excise or license tax in addition to any license tax or excise tax levied by the city, in the amount of 0.85 percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policy holders on all premiums collected on casualty insurance policies covering property within the corporate limits. 
(c)  The net proceeds of the tax assessed and collected pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, shall be allocated to and used solely for the municipal police officers' retirement trust fund of the city, pursuant to F.S. ch. 185. 
(Code 1960, § 20-8(c), (d); Ord. No. 29, §§ 3, 4; Ord. No. 193, §§ 4, 5; Code 1983, § 11-3) 
Cross reference Businesses, ch. 26; police officers pension plan, § 66-141. 
State Law reference Tax on casualty insurance for benefit of police retirement fund authorized, F.S. § 185.08; casualty insurance defined, F.S. § 185.02(4).
