ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC SERVICE TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference Utilities, ch. 86. 
State Law reference Municipal public service tax, F.S. §§ 166.231, 166.232. 
 
Sec. 78-56. - Levied; amount. 
(a)  Electricity; gas; water. There is imposed and levied by the city on each and every purchase of electricity; metered or bottled natural, liquefied, petroleum or manufactured gas; and water service within the corporate limits a tax in the amount of ten percent of the payments received by the seller of the taxable item from the purchaser for the purchase of such service. 
(b)  Telecommunications service. There is levied a seven percent tax on the purchase of telecommunications service within the city which originates and terminates in this state, excluding public telephone charges collected on site, access charges and any customer access line charges paid to a local telephone company. This tax shall be governed by F.S. § 166.231(9)(b)(d), and the applicable provisions of F.S. § 203.01. 
(c)  Fuel oil. There is imposed and levied by the city, on each and every purchase of fuel oil within the corporate limits, a tax in the amount of $0.04 per gallon, which tax shall be collected from the purchaser of such fuel oil through payment by a purchaser to the seller at the time of the purchaser's paying the charge to the seller. 
(d)  Remittance. The seller shall remit the tax to the city not less often than monthly. 
(Code 1960, § 23-4; Ord. No. 2, § 1; Ord. No. 28, § 1; Ord. No. 158, § 1; Ord. No. 159, § 1; Ord. No. 169, § 1; Ord. No. 82-31, § 1; Code 1983, § 11-21; Ord. No. 85-53, § 1, 10-15-85)  
Sec. 78-57. - Service within city. 
The purchase of the utility service upon which a tax is imposed and levied by this article shall embrace and include any part of the transaction of purchase occurring with the corporate limits, whether the transaction is the entering into a contract for the purchase of any such utility service or otherwise. 
(Code 1960, § 23-9; Ord. No. 2, § 6; Code 1983, § 11-22)  
Sec. 78-58. - Computation of tax on aggregate purchases. 
When the seller of fuel oil; electricity or metered or bottled natural, liquefied, petroleum or manufactured gas; water service; and telecommunications service collects the charge for such service at monthly periods, the tax imposed and levied by this article may be computed on the aggregate amount of purchases during such monthly period, provided the amount of the tax to be collected shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Code 1960, § 23-8; Ord. No. 2, § 5; Ord. No. 82-31, § 4; Code 1983, § 11-23)  
Sec. 78-59. - Collection by seller. 
The seller of electricity, fuel oil, and metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied, petroleum or manufactured), water service and telecommunication service, in acting as the tax collection medium or agency for the city, shall collect from the purchaser for the use of the city the tax imposed and levied under this article, at the time of collecting the purchase price charged for each transaction. The seller shall report and pay over to the finance director, on or before the 15th day of each calendar month, all such taxes imposed, levied and collected during the preceding calendar month. It shall be unlawful for any seller of such utility service to collect the price of any sale of fuel oil, electricity and metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied, petroleum gas or manufactured), water service and telecommunications service without at the same time collecting the tax imposed and levied in respect to such purchase, unless such seller shall elect to assume and pay such tax without collecting it from the purchaser. Any seller failing to collect such tax at the time of collecting the price of any purchase, where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax, shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax in like manner as if the tax had been actually paid to the seller. The city shall cause to be brought all suits and actions and to take all proceedings as may be necessary for the recovery of such tax. The seller shall not be liable for the payment of such tax upon uncollected charges. If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay the tax imposed and levied and as required on account of the purchase for which such charge is made, the seller shall have and is vested with the right, power and authority to immediately discontinue further service to such purchaser until the tax and the seller's bill shall have been paid in full. 
(Code 1960, § 23-5; Ord. No. 2, § 2; Ord. No. 412, § 45; Ord. No. 82-31, § 2; Code 1983, § 11-24)  
Sec. 78-60. - Records of seller. 
Each and every seller of electricity, fuel oil and metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied, petroleum gas or manufactured), water service and telecommunications service shall keep complete records showing all purchases in the city of such commodities or service, which records shall show the price as charged upon each purchase, the date of purchase and the date of payment, and such records shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city during business hours on all business days. The duly authorized city agents shall have the right, power, and authority to make such transcripts of such records during such time as they may desire. 
(Code 1960, § 23-6; Ord. No. 2, § 3; Ord. No. 82-31, § 3; Code 1983, § 11-25)  
Sec. 78-61. - Failure to pay tax. 
Any purchaser willfully failing, refusing, or neglecting to pay the tax imposed and levied in this article where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax, and any seller willfully violating this article or any officer, agent, or employee of the seller violating this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalties provided by section 1-14. 
(Code 1960, § 23-10; Ord. No. 2, § 7; Code 1983, § 11-27)  
Sec. 78-62. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The United States, the state and the political subdivisions and authorities thereof and county and municipal governments are exempted from payment of the tax imposed and levied by this article upon the services used by such governmental agencies. 
(b)  Recognized churches are exempt from the tax on purchases or services used exclusively for church purposes. 
(Code 1960, § 23-7; Ord. No. 2, § 4; Code 1983, § 11-26) 
State Law reference Exemptions, F.S. § 166.231.  
Secs. 78-6378-89. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - LOCAL BUSINESS TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, adopted April 10, 2007, amended Art. IV to read as herein set out. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Art. IV was entitled, "Occupational License Tax." See also the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 
Cross reference Adult entertainment establishments, § 10-26 et seq.; businesses, ch. 26; registration of businesses not subject to local license tax, § 26-1; noise regulations, § 46-131 et seq.; commercial solicitation, § 62-26 et seq.; contract required for private collectors of solid waste, § 70-126; vehicles for hire, ch. 90. 
State Law reference Local license tax, F.S. ch. 205. 
 
Sec. 78-90. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
Business, profession, and occupation do not include the customary religious, charitable, or educational activities of nonprofit religious, nonprofit charitable, and nonprofit educational institutions, which institutions are more particularly defined and limited as follows: 
(1)  Religious institutions means churches and ecclesiastical or denominational organizations or established physical places for worship in this state at which nonprofit religious services and activities are regularly conducted and carried on, and also means church cemeteries; 
(2)  Educational institutions means state tax-supported or parochial, church and nonprofit private schools, colleges, or universities conducting regular classes and courses of study required for accreditation by or membership in the Southern association of Colleges and Schools, the Department of Education, or the Florida Council of Independent schools. Nonprofit libraries, art galleries, and museums open to the public are defined as educational institutions and eligible for exemption; and 
(3)  Charitable institutions means only nonprofit corporations operating physical facilities in this state at which are provided charitable services, a reasonable percentage of which are without cost to those unable to pay. 
Classification means the method by which a business or group of businesses is identified by size or type, or both. 
Local business tax means the fees charged and the method by which the city grants the privilege of engaging in or managing any business, profession, or occupation within its jurisdiction. It does not mean any fees or licenses paid to any board, commission, or office for permits, registration, examination, or inspection. Unless otherwise provided by law, these are deemed to be regulatory and in addition to, but not in lieu of any local business tax imposed under the provisions of this chapter. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, joint adventure, syndicate, or other group or combination acting as a unit, association, corporation, estate, trust, business trust, trustee, executer, administrator, receiver or other. 
Receipt means the document that is issued by the city which bears the words "local business tax receipt" and evidences that the person in whose name the document is issued has complied with the provisions of this chapter relating to the local business tax. 
Taxpayer means any person liable for taxes imposed under the provisions of this article; any agent required to file and pay taxes imposed hereunder; and the heirs, successors, assignees, and transferees of any such person or agent. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-91. - Levied. 
(a)  Local business taxes in the amounts specified in section 78-110 are levied on: 
(1)  Any person who maintains a permanent business location or branch office within the city, for the privilege of engaging in or managing any business within the city. 
(2)  Any person who maintains a permanent business location or branch office within the city for the privilege of engaging in or managing any profession or occupation within the city. 
(3)  Any person who does not qualify under subsection (a)(1) or (2) of this section and who transacts any business or engages in any occupation or profession in interstate commerce, if such business tax is not prohibited by section 8 of article I of the United States Constitution. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct any business upon which is levied a local business tax without first paying such tax to the city. 
(c)  A separate local business tax shall be levied on each branch establishment or location where a separate business is conducted, provided that warehouses and distributing plants used in connection with and incidental to a business licensed under this article shall not be deemed to be separate places of business or branch establishments. Each rental real property shall be deemed a branch establishment or separate place of business for the purposes of this article when there is a representative of the owner or the owner's agent on the premises who is authorized to transact business for such owner or owner's agent or there is a regular employee of the owner or of the owner's agent working on the premises. A real estate broker or agent, having a "for rent" or "for sale" sign on one or more premises within the city, shall be deemed to be doing business within the city. 
(d)  A person engaged in two or more businesses at the same location shall not be required to obtain separate business tax receipts for conducting each of such businesses, unless otherwise provided in this article, but, when eligible, shall be issued one tax receipt for the highest amount payable for any one of the businesses and shall be charged a tax equal to one-half of the tax required for each additional business. Such additional businesses shall be specified on the face of the receipt. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-92. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The city manager shall issue business tax receipts in the name of the city to all persons qualified under this article and shall: 
(1)  Promulgate and enforce all reasonable rules and regulations necessary to the operation and enforcement of this article; 
(2)  Prescribe and provide all forms and information to be given therein as to character and other relevant matter for all necessary papers; 
(3)  Require applicants to submit all affidavits and oaths necessary to the administration of this article; 
(4)  Submit all applications, in a proper case, to interested city officials for their endorsements thereon as to compliance by the applicant with all city regulations which they have the duty of enforcing; 
(5)  Investigate and determine the eligibility of any applicant for a local business tax receipt as prescribed in this article; 
(6)  Examine the books and records of any applicant or receipt holder when reasonably necessary to the administration and enforcement of this article; and 
(7)  Notify any applicant of the acceptance or rejection of his or her application and shall, upon the city manager's refusal to issue any receipt, at the applicant's request, state in writing the reasons therefor and deliver them to the applicant. 
(b)  When the issuance of a business tax receipt is denied and any action is instituted by the applicant to compel its issuance, such applicant shall not engage in the business for which the receipt was refused unless issuance of the license is ordered by final judgment of the court. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-93. - Inspections and reports. 
(a)  The city manager shall make all investigations reasonably necessary to the enforcement of this article. The manager shall have the authority to order the inspection of receipt holders, their businesses and premises, by all city officials having duties to perform with reference to such receipt holders or businesses. 
(b)  The police officers shall inspect and examine businesses located within their respective jurisdictions or beats to enforce compliance with this article. 
(c)  The fire marshal and director of community development shall have authority to order inspections or conduct inspections under the building code, the mechanical code, the plumbing code, the electrical code, the life safety code, the gas code, the fire prevention code, and any other codes adopted by the city. 
(d)  All persons authorized in this section to inspect receipt holders and businesses shall have the authority to enter, with or without search warrant, at all reasonable times, the premises for which business tax receipt: 
(1)  Is required; 
(2)  Was issued and which, at the time of inspection, is operating under such receipt; or 
(3)  Has been revoked or suspended. 
(e)  Persons inspecting receipt holders, their businesses or premises as authorized in this section shall report all violations of all laws or ordinances to the city manager, and shall submit such other report as the city manager shall order. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-94. - Collection remedies. 
Any unpaid tax required by this article shall constitute a debt due the city. The city attorney shall, at the direction of the city manager, institute civil suit in the name of the city to recover any such unpaid tax. No civil judgment or any act by the city attorney, the city manager or the violator shall bar or prevent a prosecution for each and every violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-95. - Refund. 
No rebate or refund of any local business tax or part thereof shall be made because of the nonuse of the business tax receipt or because of a change of location or business rendering the use of such tax receipt ineffective. A rebate or refund of the business tax may be made only if the business tax was collected through error. Proof of grounds for rebate shall be submitted to the city manager in the form of an affidavit, and the decision of the city manager shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-96. - Business tax receiptRequired. 
No person shall engage in any business, trade or profession in the city without first obtaining a business tax receipt issued by the city manager and paying the tax required pursuant to this article. The issuance of a business tax receipt for a business on any premises within the city shall not constitute, nor be construed as, approval by the city of the land use, zoning or other developmental approval of the particular business on the premises for which such receipt was issued. Businesses operating in association with city sponsored special events may be exempted from this requirement upon approval of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07; Ord. No. 08-20, § 3, 5-13-08)  
Sec. 78-97. - Application procedures; proration of tax. 
(a)  Every person required to pay a tax under this article or any section of this Code or other city ordinance shall submit, if requested or required, a declaration form to the city manager. The declaration form shall: 
(1)  Be a written statement upon forms provided by the city manager. Such form shall include an affidavit to be sworn to by the applicant. 
(2)  Require the disclosure of all information necessary to complete the application form. If the applicant starts his business on or after April 1 of the year of application and prior to October 1 next succeeding, the applicant shall be required to pay only one-half of the annual tax and shall receive a license for the balance of the taxable year. 
(b)  Whenever a business tax receipt cannot be issued at the time the application for the receipt is made, the city manager shall issue a receipt to the applicant for the application fee in advance. Such receipt shall not be construed as the approval of the city manager for the issuance of a business tax receipt, and it shall not entitle or authorize the applicant to open or maintain any business contrary to this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-98. - Fee. 
At the time an application is submitted, an business tax receipt application fee, in an amount established by resolution of the city commission and listed in appendix A to this Code, shall be paid to the city. This fee shall be nonrefundable and in addition to the business tax in section 78-110 and any inspection fees. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-99. - Business tax receipt exemption for rental of individual room in home. 
No business tax receipt shall be required of any person where that person is renting no more than one individual room within his home where authorized under chapter 134 and such rental is not incidental to a business requiring a business tax receipt for guest accommodation. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-100. - Issuance of business tax receipt. 
(a)  The city manager shall deny business tax receipt to any business whose proposed operation would violate any law or ordinance. 
(b)  No business tax receipt shall be issued by the city to any person required by state law to be registered and issued a certificate to practice any profession or engage in any business unless such person in applying for a receipt shall submit proof of having been duly qualified to practice the profession or engage in the business under the state law. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-101. - Contents of receipt. 
Every business tax receipt shall state upon its face the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the receipt holder and any other name under which such business is to be conducted; 
(2)  The nature of each business for which such receipt is issued; 
(3)  The amount of the local business tax; 
(4)  The dates of issuance and expiration; and 
(5)  Such other information as the city manager shall determine. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-102. - Posting of receipt and insignia. 
Every business tax receipt holder shall: 
(1)  Post and maintain the business tax receipt upon the permitted premises in a place where it may be seen at all times; 
(2)  Affix any insignia delivered for use in connection with business tax receipts on the inside glass part of the window of such establishment facing the public way or on the inside glass part of the door opening on the public way. Such insignia shall be placed and maintained so as to be plainly visible from the public way. Premises not fronting on a public way at street level or having a glass door opening upon the public way shall have the insignia displayed in the door, window, or other prominent place in the nearest proximity to the principal public entrance to such establishment, and the insignia shall be placed and maintained so as to be plainly visible from such public entrance; 
(3)  Affix any insignia delivered for use in connection with a motor vehicle, for which such receipt has been issued, on the windshield of the vehicle or as may be otherwise required by the city manager or by law; 
(4)  Affix any metal or other durable type of insignia delivered for use in connection with a wagon or other vehicle, not operated by motor power, securely on the outside of such vehicle; 
(5)  Carry such receipt on his or her person when he or she has no business premises; 
(6)  Affix any insignia delivered for use in connection therewith upon the outside of any coin-operated vending or other business machine or device, so that it may be seen at all times; and 
(7)  Not allow any business tax receipt or insignia to remain posted or displayed or used after the period for which it was issued has expired or when it has been suspended or revoked or for any other reason it becomes ineffective. The receipt holder shall promptly return such ineffective receipt or insignia to the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-103. - Expiration, renewal of receipt; penalties. 
(a)  Expiration. A business tax receipt issued pursuant to this article shall expire on September 30 of each year. 
(b)  Renewal. An expired business tax receipt shall be renewable beginning August 1 of each year, being due and payable on or before September 30 of each year, and shall expire on September 30 of the succeeding year. If September 30 falls on a weekend or holiday, the tax is due and payable on or before the first working day following September 30. 
(c)  Penalties for late payment. If the business tax has not been paid in accordance with this section, a ten percent penalty shall be charged for any payment made during the month of October, plus an additional five percent penalty for each subsequent month of delinquency until the tax has been paid. However, the total delinquency penalty shall not exceed 25 percent of the business tax due for the person or business entity required to pay such tax. 
(d)  Failure to obtain required receipt. Any person engaging in or managing any business, occupation, or profession without first obtaining a local business tax receipt, if required by this Code, shall be subject to a penalty of 25 percent of the business tax determined to be due, in addition to any other penalty provided by law or ordinance. 
(e)  Additional penalties. Any person who engages in any business, occupation or profession covered by this article who does not pay the required business tax within 150 days after the initial notice of tax and who does not obtain the required business tax receipt is subject to civil actions and penalties, including court costs, reasonable attorneys' fees, additional administrative costs incurred as a result of collection efforts, and a monthly penalty of ten percent of the annual business tax, up to 50 percent of the annual business tax or $250.00, whichever is less. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the city from citing any person or business entity in violation of this subsection for each day the violation occurs or is in existence, including citations made daily. Each such citation shall be separately made and constitute a single violation punishable as described in section 1-14. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-104. - Duplicate business tax receipts. 
A duplicate business tax receipt shall be issued by the city manager to replace any tax receipt previously issued, which has been lost, stolen, defaced, or destroyed, without any willful conduct on the part of the receipt holder, upon filing by the receipt holder of an affidavit sworn to before a notary public of this state attesting to such fact. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-105. - Transferability of business tax receipt. 
(a)  Except as may be otherwise prohibited by state law, a business tax receipt holder shall have the right to transfer the receipt to another person, provided he or she shall: 
(1)  Provide satisfactory written evidence to the city manager that there has been a bona fide sale of business; 
(2)  Execute the transfer in the manner prescribed by the city manager; 
(3)  Report the completed act of transfer to the city manager within 30 days of the sale of the business; 
(4)  Surrender any receipt and, when required by the city manager, all insignia within 30 days of sale of the business; and 
(5)  Pay a transfer fee of ten percent of the annual business tax, but not less than nor more than the amounts established by resolution of the city commission and listed in appendix A to this Code. 
(b)  Upon written request and presentation of the original business tax receipt, any receipt may be transferred from one location to another location in the city upon payment of a transfer fee of ten percent of the annual business tax, but not less than nor more than the amounts established by resolution of the city commission and listed in appendix A to this Code. 
(c)  Upon the completion of a written request for transfer of a business tax receipt and compliance with this article, the city manager shall issue a new receipt and insignia to the transferee for the unexpired term of the old receipt. The new receipt issued under subsection (a) of this section shall authorize the transferee named in the new receipt to engage in the same business at the same location or at such other place as shall be approved by the city manager pursuant to subsection (b) of this section. Transfer of a business tax receipt does not exempt the transferee from complying with any and all applicable ordinances regulating the business. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-106. - Order to cease and desist; revocation or suspension of receipt. 
(a)  Order to cease and desist. 
(1)  When a violation of any law or ordinance has been observed by or reported to the department of community development (hereinafter, "the department"), the director of the department or any of his designated officials shall issue an order to cease and desist (hereinafter, "the order"). The order shall be in writing, shall be personally served upon the person or entity named in the order and shall set forth the violation for which the order was issued. Service of the order shall be made at the address set forth on the business tax receipt, and shall be directed to the person named as owner or operator of the business for which the receipt was issued. If the owner of the receipt is a corporation, partnership or other business entity, then service shall be made upon the person holding or owning the tax receipt. If the owner or operator of the business cannot be found on the premises of the business, then service may be made upon any manager or other person in charge of the premises for which the tax receipt was issued. 
(2)  The cease and desist order shall require the owner or holder of the business tax receipt to cease and desist from further violating, or from further violations of, the ordinances of the city, or from any applicable state or county statute or ordinance, applicable to the premises for which such receipt was issued, within 30 days from the date of service of the order. Provided that for good cause shown, the director may extend the time for compliance with the order. 
(3)  The person or business entity to whom the order to cease and desist has been issued pursuant to this section shall be entitled to appeal the issuance of the order in the manner provided in section 78-107. An appeal pursuant to this provision shall act as an automatic stay of the cease and desist order until the appeal has been decided. 
(b)  Revocation of suspension of receipt. If the person or business entity to whom the cease and desist order has been issued fails to comply with the order within the time set forth in this section, the director or the designated official shall be entitled to and shall have the authority to suspend or revoke the business tax receipt of the business for which the order was issued or take such action as may be appropriate to correct the problem for which the cease and desist order was issued. Upon any revocation or suspension, the owner or holder of the receipt shall immediately cease all business operating under the tax receipt. If the city is required to seek injunctive relief to enforce the provisions of this section, it shall be entitled to recover its reasonable attorneys' fees expended in order to enforce the cease and desist order. Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the city from pursuing any and all legal remedies available to it, including but not limited to criminal prosecution of the receipt owner, or holder or the manager of the premises for which such receipt was issued, and any employees found to be working on the premises at the expiration of the 30 days given for compliance with the order. 
(c)  Summary order. When the conduct of any receipt holder is so inimical to the public health, safety and general welfare as to constitute a nuisance and thus give rise to an emergency, the director or the designated official shall have the authority to issue a summary order requiring the cessation of business and the close of premises, or suspending or revoking the permit. Unless waived in writing, within 30 days after the issuance of the summary order, the director or his designated official shall conduct a special hearing for such action in respect to the summary order as may be therein determined. Notice of such hearing shall be given the affected person in the manner prescribed in this section. 
(d)  Hearing. The hearing held in accordance with this section shall be conducted by an independent hearing officer designated by the city manager and not an employee of the city, and whose decision shall be binding upon the parties. Either party may appeal the hearing officer's decision pursuant to section 78-107. 
(e)  Revocation for violation of article. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) through (d) of this section, upon conviction in a court of a violation of any provisions of this article the business tax receipt issued to the party convicted shall be immediately and automatically thereby revoked. 
(f)  Revocation for cause. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a) through (e) of this section, the city commission reserves the right to revoke any business tax receipt for cause. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-107. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by any decision of the director or his designated official made pursuant to this article, after hearing, shall have the right to appeal to the city commission by filing a written appeal with the city clerk's office within ten days following the effective date of the action or decision complained of and by paying the prescribed fee as set by resolution of the city commission in effect at the time of appeal. 
(b)  Such appeal shall set out a copy of the order or decision appealed from, and shall include a statement of the facts relied upon to reverse such order. At the time of filing any such appeal, a copy thereof shall be filed by the appellant with director or his designated official. 
(c)  All appeals shall be heard by a hearing officer designated by the city commission no later than 30 days from receipt of the appeal. Appellant shall be served with a written notice of appeals hearing stating the date, place and time of the hearing. The notice of appeals hearing shall be personally served upon the receipt holder, either to his or her attorney, if represented by counsel, or shall be made at the address set forth on the tax receipt; and shall be directed to the person named as owner or operator of the business for which the receipt was issued. If the owner of the receipt is a corporation, partnership or other business entity, then service shall be made upon the person holding or owning the tax receipt. If the owner or operator of the business cannot be found on the premises of the business, then service may be made upon any manager or other person in charge of the premises for which the tax receipt was issued. Service of the notice of appeals hearing shall be made within five business days of its issuance. The city commission shall also give such notice to the director or his designated official, and such officer shall be entitled to appear and defend such order, or to present his appeal. The findings of the city commission shall be final and conclusive, and shall be personally served upon the appellant as required in this section. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-108. - Records. 
A person issued a business tax receipt shall keep all records and books necessary to the computation of his business tax and to the enforcement of this article. When the receipt holder has failed to keep the books and records required in this article, the city manager shall make his own determination as to the financial statement for the business of such receipt holder. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-109. - General standards of conduct. 
Every business tax receipt holder shall: 
(1)  Permit all reasonable inspections of his business and examinations of his books by public authorities so authorized by law; 
(2)  Ascertain and at all times comply with all laws and regulations applicable to his business; 
(3)  Avoid all forbidden, improper or unnecessary practices or conditions which do or may affect the public health, morals, or welfare; and 
(4)  Refrain from operating the business for which such receipt was issued on such premises after expiration of the receipt and during the period the receipt and privilege of doing business in the city is revoked or suspended pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1, 4-10-07)  
Sec. 78-110. - Tax schedule. 
The occupational license taxes levied by section 78-91 shall be as follows: 
A

b.  610 units inclusive ..... 30.00

d.  Maximum tax ..... 300.00

(7)  Armored car service ..... 50.00

Portrait sketching ..... 50.00

ARTICLE V. - HISTORIC PROPERTY TAX EXEMPTION 
 
Sec. 78-111. - Short title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as the "City of St. Pete Beach Historic Property Tax Exemption Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-112. - Purpose and intent. 
It is the intent of the city commission to foster the preservation and renovation of historic properties in the city by providing incentives to restore, renovate or rehabilitate historic structures through the implementation of F.S. §§ 196.1997 and 196.1998 relating to the exemption of certain ad valorem taxes for historic properties. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-113. - Definitions. 
[The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
Applicant means the owner of record of a property or the authorized agent of the owner. 
Application means the two-part historic preservation property tax exemption application, DOS Form No. HR3E101292, effective 1-31-94. This form may be obtained through the city planning department, or by writing the Bureau of Historic Preservation, 500 South Bronough Street, Tallahassee, Florida 32399-0250, or from the local historic preservation office. 
Assessed value means the total value of a tax parcel (including structures, land and other rights appurtenant thereto) as determined by the county property appraiser and shown on the property tax bill sent to the owner of record by the county. 
Board of county commissioners means the Pinellas County Board of County Commissioners. 
Certificate of appropriateness means a written authorization by the county administrator to the owner(s) of a designated property, or any building, structure or site within a designated historic district, allowing a proposed alteration, relocation, or the demolition of a building, structure, or site. A certificate of appropriateness is required for any proposed work that will result in the alteration, demolition, relocation, reconstruction, new construction or excavation of a designated historic resource. 
City commission means the City Commission of the City of St. Pete Beach. 
Contributing property means and includes any building, structure or site which contributes to the overall historic significance of a designated historic district and was present during the period of historic significance and possesses historic integrity reflecting the character of that time or is capable of yielding important information about the historically significant period or independently meets the criteria for designation as an historic resource. 
Covenant means the historic preservation tax exemption covenant required to be recorded with the deed for the property in the official records of the county to obtain an exemption pursuant to this ordinance. 
Designation means action by the city commission to approve an historic preservation overlay zoning district for (a) parcel(s) of land or district. 
Division of historical resources means the Division of Historical Resources of the State of Florida. 
Exemption means the ad valorem tax exemption for historic properties authorized pursuant to this ordinance. 
Historic district means an area designated as historic pursuant to Section 28 of the City of St. Pete Beach Land Development Code or that is listed in the National Register of Historic Places. 
Historic property means a property that is designated as an historic property, or as a contributing property to an historic district, by the historic preservation regulations found in Section 28 of the City of St. Pete Beach Land Development Code, or is listed in the National Register of Historic Places. 
Improvements means changes in the condition of real property brought about by the expenditure of labor or money for the restoration, renovation or rehabilitation of such property. Improvements include additions and accessory structures (i.e. a garage) necessary for efficient contemporary use. 
Local historic preservation office means the Planning Department of the City of St. Pete Beach. 
National Register of Historic Places means the list of historic properties significant in American history, architecture, archaeology, engineering and culture, maintained by the Secretary of the Interior, as established by the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 (Public Law 89-665:80 STAT. 915; 16 U.S.C. 470), as amended. 
Renovation or rehabilitation means the act or process of returning a property to a state of utility through repair or alteration which makes possible an efficient contemporary use while preserving those portions or features of the property which are significant to its historical, architectural, cultural and archaeological values. 
Restoration means the act or process of accurately recovering the form and details of a property and its setting as it appeared at a particular period of time by means of the removal of later work or by the replacement of missing earlier work. 
Usable space means that portion of the space within a building which is available for assignment or rental to an occupant, including every type of space available for use of the occupant. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-114. - Property and improvements eligible for tax exemption; area embraced. 
(a)  This article shall govern and be applicable to all property located in the City of St. Pete Beach provided that the property meets the following qualifications: 
(1)  The property is individually listed in the National Register of Historic Places pursuant to the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966, as amended; or 
(2)  The property is a contributing property to a National Register-listed-district; or 
(3)  The property is designated as an historic property, or as a contributing property to an historic district, by the historic preservation regulations found in Division 28 of the St. Pete Beach Land Development Code. 
(b)  In order for an improvement to qualify a property for an exemption, the improvement must: 
(1)  Be consistent with the United States Secretary of Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation; and 
(2)  Be determined by the local historic preservation office to meet criteria established in rules adopted by the Department of State, Chapter 1A-38, F.A.C.; and 
(3)  Be completed within two years from the date of approval of a complete preconstruction application. A preconstruction application approval shall automatically be revoked if the property owner has not submitted a request for review of completed work within two years following the date of approval of a preconstruction application. The local historic preservation office may grant an extension to this provision for up to six months if such request is made in writing prior to the expiration of the initial period; and 
(4)  Contain a minimum of $2,500.00 worth of improvements to the exterior of the property, unless it has been documented that no improvements to the exterior of the property are needed; and 
(5)  Meet the certificate of appropriateness requirements for a qualifying restoration, renovation, or rehabilitation, if applicable, under the conditions of Division 28 of the St. Pete Beach Land Development Code. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-115. - Duration and amount of tax exemptions. 
Any tax exemption granted by this ordinance shall remain in effect for ten years regardless of any change in the authority of the city commission to grant such exemptions or any change in the ownership of the property, except as set forth in section 111-8 and in section 111-10(b) of this article. Improvements which qualified the property for an exemption must be maintained over the period for which the exemption is granted. The tax exemption amount will be determined by the assessed value of the improvements as determined by the county property appraiser's office and will be fixed in amount for the length of the exemption period based on the assessed value of the improvements at the year the improvements are completed. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-116. - Applicable taxes. 
The tax exemption allowed herein are only ad valorem taxes assessed by the Pinellas County Board of County Commissioners and the City of St. Pete Beach City Commission and include the following: 
(1)  Pinellas County Government; 
(2)  Pinellas County Health; 
(3)  Pinellas County Mosquito Control; 
(4)  Pinellas Planning Council; 
(5)  Pinellas County Municipal Services Taxing District; 
(6)  City of St. Pete Beach Operating 
The exemptions do not apply to taxes levied for the payment of bonds or to taxes authorized by a vote of the electors pursuant to Section 9(b) or Section 12, Article VII of the Florida Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-117. - Ad valorem tax exemptions for improvements to historic property authorized: limitations. 
The city commission may authorize an exemption from ad valorem taxation equal to 100 percent of the assessed value of all improvements to historic properties which result from the restoration, renovation or rehabilitation of such properties. The exemption applies only to improvements to real property. In order for the property to qualify for the exemption, any such improvements must be made on or after the effective date of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-118. - Ad valorem tax exemptions for historic properties open to the public. 
If a property is used for nonprofit or governmental purposes, and is regularly and frequently open for the public's visitation, use and benefit, as defined in Chapter lA-38, F.A.C., the city commission may exempt 100 percent of the assessed value of the property as improved from ad valorem taxes levied by the city commission provided that the assessed value of the qualifying improvement is equal to at least 50 percent of the total assessed value of the property as improved. This section applies only if the qualifying improvements are made by or for the use of the existing property owner. In order for the property to qualify for the exemption provided in this section, any such improvements must be made on or after the effective date of this ordinance. 
A property is considered used for nonprofit or governmental purposes if the occupant or the user of at least 65 percent of the useable space of the building is an agency of the federal, state, or local government or a nonprofit corporation whose articles of incorporation have been filed by the Department of State in accordance with F.S. § 617.0125. A property is considered regularly and frequently open to the public if public access to the property is provided not less than 52 days a year on an equitably spaced basis, and at other times by appointment. This exemption does not prohibit the owner from charging a reasonable nondiscriminatory admission fee. If a property that qualifies for this exemption is no longer regularly and frequently open to the public, or if ownership is transferred, then this exemption shall be subject to the revocation proceedings of section 78-114 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-119. - Application. 
(a)  Preconstruction application. Any person, firm, or corporation that desires an ad valorem tax exemption for the improvement of an historic property must submit to the local historic preservation office a preconstruction application on a form prescribed by the Department of State. The preconstruction application must receive approval prior to the start of construction. An improvement or any portion thereof initiated prior to approval of the preconstruction application shall not be eligible for the exemption. The application must include the following information: 
(1)  The name of the property owner and the location of the historic property; and 
(2)  A description of the improvements to real property for which an exemption is requested and the anticipated date of commencement of construction of such improvements. This includes an estimate of the cost of the improvements that will be done to the exterior of the property or documentation that no improvements to the exterior of the property are necessary; and 
(3)  Proof, to the satisfaction of the local historic preservation office, that the property that is to be restored, renovated, or rehabilitated is an historic property under this ordinance; and 
(4)  Proof, to the satisfaction of the local historic preservation office, that the improvements to the property will be consistent with the United States Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation and will be made in accordance with guidelines developed by the Department of State, Chapter 1A-38, F.A.C.; and 
(5)  Other information identified in appropriate Department of State regulations; and 
(6)  Other information requested by the local historic preservation office or requested by the city commission; and 
(7)  If necessary, a completed application for a certificate of appropriateness for the qualifying restoration, renovation, or rehabilitation. On completion of the review of a preconstruction application, the local historic preservation office shall notify the applicant in writing of the results of the review and shall make recommendations for correction of any planned work deemed to be inconsistent with section 111-4(b) of this article. Any changes made to the improvement after approval of the preconstruction application must receive prior approval of the local historic preservation office to ensure compliance with the criteria set forth in this ordinance. Failure to obtain prior approval may result in denial of the exemption. 
(b)  Request for review of completed work application. A request for review of completed work application shall be submitted to the local historic preservation office upon completion of the improvements. The form of said application shall be prescribed by the Department of State and shall include all information referenced in subsection (a) of this section. The local historic preservation office shall review the request for review of completed work application and provide to the board of county commissioners a written recommendation of either approval or denial of the application. The review by the local historic preservation office will be conducted in accordance with rules adopted by the Department of State, Chapter 1A-38, F.A.C. The local historic preservation office reserves the right to inspect the completed work to verify that it is in compliance with the work described in the approved preconstruction application. In order for an improvement to an historic property to qualify the property for an exemption, the improvement must meet the requirements of section 111-4(b) of this article. 
(c)  Interior inspection. Upon receipt of a preconstruction application or a request for review of completed work application involving an improvement project in which some of the work is in the interior of the property, the local historic preservation office reserves the right to make arrangements with the applicant for an interior inspection. The purpose of the interior inspection is to ascertain the effect, if any, of the improvement project on significant historical or architectural interior features. In order to determine the assessed value of an improvement project in which some of the work is in the interior of the property, the county property appraiser's office reserves the right to make arrangements with the applicant for an interior inspection after a tax exemption has been granted by the city commission. 
(d)  Reapplication. A property owner previously granted an exemption may undertake additional improvements during the exemption period or apply for additional exemptions for additional improvements following the expiration of the exemption period. A property owner may not reapply for an exemption for an improvement which has been denied by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-120. - Required covenant. 
(a)  To qualify for an exemption, the property owner must enter into a covenant with the city commission for the term for which the exemption is granted. The form of the covenant must be approved by the Department of State. The covenant shall provide that the property owner shall maintain and repair the property so as to preserve and maintain the historic architectural qualities or historical or archaeological integrity of the property during the period that the exemption is granted. If the exemption is granted, the property owner shall have the covenant recorded with the deed for the property in the official records of the county prior to the effective date of the exemption and shall provide a certified copy of the recorded covenant to the city manager within 30 days of city commission approval or said approval by the city commission shall be void. The covenant shall be binding on the current property owner, transferees, and their heirs, successors, or assigns. Violation of the covenant results in the property owner being subject to the payment of the differences between the total amount of taxes which would have been due in March in each of the previous years in which the covenant was in effect had the property not received the exemption and the total amount of taxes actually paid in those years, plus interest on the difference calculated as provided in F.S. § 212.12(3). 
(b)  If the property changes ownership during the exemption period, the requirements of the covenant must be transferred to the new owner. The new property owner may sign a waiver which discontinues the exemption on the property with no penalty to the property owner. The exemption may not be reinstated after the waiver has been delivered to the city manager. A copy of the waiver will be delivered to the county property appraiser's office. For waivers received prior to July 1 by the property appraiser's office, the exemption will be discontinued in that tax year. For waivers received after July 1 by the property appraiser's office, the exemption will be discontinued in the following tax year. 
(c)  One historic property tax exemption covenant may be executed by the property owner to include both the City of St. Pete Beach and Pinellas County. The property owner must provide a certified copy of the recorded covenant to both the city manager and to the county administrator, or his or her designee. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-121. - City commission review and action. 
On completion of any municipal action on an application, the local historic preservation office shall deliver a copy of the application, their recommendation to grant or deny the tax exemption and the reasons therefore to the city commission. The city commission may then approve, modify, defer, or deny an application for tax exemption by resolution. If approved by the city commission, such tax exemption shall take effect on the January 1 following the resolution approving the tax exemption. Said approval shall be conditioned upon receipt by the city manager, or his or her designee, of a certified copy of the recorded covenant. The resolution approving the tax exemption shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  The name of the owner and the address of the historic property for which the exemption is granted. 
(2)  The period of time for which the exemption will remain in effect and the expiration date of the exemption. 
(3)  A finding that the historic property meets the requirements of this ordinance. 
(4)  Any conditions of approval. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-122. - Notice to Pinellas County Board of Commissioners. 
The city commission shall deliver to the Pinellas County Board of Commissioners a copy of each approved application for an historic property ad valorem tax exemption within five working days of said approval. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-123. - Notice to property appraiser. 
The city commission shall deliver to the county property appraiser a copy of each application for an historic property ad valorem tax exemption approved in the previous calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 78-124. - Revocation proceedings. 
The city commission may revoke an exemption at any time in the event that the property owner, or any subsequent owner or successor in interest to the property, violates the covenant, fails to maintain the qualifying property according to the terms, conditions and standards of the covenant, the historic character of the property and improvements which qualified the property for the exemption are not maintained, or if the property has been damaged by accidental or natural causes to the extent that the historic integrity of the features, materials, appearances, workmanship and environment, or archaeological integrity which made it eligible for listing or designation have been lost or damaged so that restoration is not possible. The city manager shall provide notice of such proceedings to the owner of record of the property. The city commissioner shall determine whether, and under what conditions the exemption shall be revoked, and whether and in what amount the property owner owes back taxes pursuant to section 111-10(a) of this article. The city commission shall provide written notice of the decision to the owner of record and to the county property appraiser. The local historic preservation office of the City of St. Pete Beach shall notify the county administrator's office, or his or her designee, of the proceedings and the reasons therefor. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Chapter 82 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Consumption or possession of open containers of alcoholic beverages in public places prohibited, § 6-5; identification of commercial vehicles required, § 26-2; emergency procedures during hurricanes, § 34-1; distribution of handbills restricted, § 46-1; noise regulations, § 46-131 et seq.; motor vehicle noise restrictions, § 46-147; skateboards and motorized vehicles restrictions in parks and recreation areas, § 58-6; streets and sidewalks, ch. 74; skateboarding prohibited, § 74-1; vehicles for hire, ch. 90; permits required for vehicles on the beach, § 94-73. 
State Law reference Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166; Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, F.S. ch. 316; restrictions on power of municipality to regulate traffic, F.S. §§ 316.006316.008. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 82-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
"Commuter vehicle" means a motor vehicle parked in a residential area by a person who is not a resident of the designated residential area. 
"Controlled parking residential area" means a contiguous or nearly contiguous area containing streets or parts thereof primarily abutted by property which has a specific residential zone designation on the official zoning map and which is designated for restricted residential parking by the city manager, pursuant to criteria and procedures established in this chapter. 
"Dwelling" means a room or group of rooms forming a single independent habitable unit used for or intended to be used for living, sleeping, sanitation, cooking, and eating purposes by one family only; for owner occupancy or for lease; and containing independent kitchen, sanitary and sleeping facilities. A dwelling does not include motels, hotels, and other transient accommodation uses. 
"Resident" means a person who owns or leases real property within the city, as evidenced by a form listed in section 82-2. 
"Residential parking permit" means a special permit issued under this chapter for the privilege of parking on a street designated as a "controlled parking residential area." 
(Ord. No. 2016-04, § 1, 4-12-16)  
Sec. 82-2. - Requirements for issuance of parking permits. 
The following shall be required at the time of issuance: 
(1)  A valid driver's license. 
(2)  Proof of residency in one of the following forms shall be required for all annual parking permits: 
a.  Voter registration card; 
b.  Real estate tax bill; 
c.  Lease agreement for a period of at least six consecutive months within the year of issuance; 
d.  Driver's license with current address; 
e.  Utility bill with current address; or 
f.  Three pieces of mail with current address. 
(3)  Proof of employment in one of the following forms shall be required for all annual parking permits for employees and owners of businesses in accordance with section 82-202: 
a.  A current paycheck stub with the applicant's name. 
b.  A letter signed by the owner of the business stating the applicant is currently employed at that location. 
c.  A current business tax license issued by the City of St. Pete Beach that contains the applicant's name. 
(d)  In the event that a resident cannot produce any of the above documents, the resident will immediately be referred to a supervisor who will assist the resident by looking for other possible ways to provide satisfactory proof of residency that may be approved by the community development director. 
(e)  Current vehicle registration shall also be required for issuance of all annual parking permits. Hang tags shall be exempt from this requirement. 
(f)  Payment in accordance with appendix A of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2016-04, § 1, 4-12-16)  
Sec. 82-3. - Penalty. 
Except as otherwise provided, anyone violating the provisions of this chapter shall be punished according to the penalties set out in F.S. § 316.655. 
(Code 1960, § 24-1; Ord. No. 216, § 10; Code 1983, § 21-4) 
Editor's note With the codification of Ord. No. 2016-04 in §§ 82-1 and 82-2 and at the direction of the city, the existing §§ 82-1 and 82-2 have been renumbered as §§ 82-3 and 82-4, as herein set out.  
Sec. 82-4. - Unattended motor vehicles. 
No person driving or in charge of any motor vehicle, except a licensed delivery truck or other delivery vehicle making deliveries, shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition and removing the key. No vehicle shall be permitted to stand unattended upon any perceptible grade without stopping the engine and effectively setting the brake thereon. 
(Code 1960, § 24-28(a); Ord. No. 216, § 4; Ord. No. 275, § 1; Ord. No. 399, § 2; Code 1983, § 21-22) 
Editor's note With the codification of Ord. No. 2016-04 in §§ 82-1 and 82-2 and at the direction of the city, the existing §§ 82-1 and 82-2 have been renumbered as §§ 82-3 and 82-4, as herein set out. 
State Law reference Similar provisions, F.S. § 316.1975.  
Secs. 82-582-29. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SPECIFIC STREET REGULATIONS[2]

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 82-30. - Traffic control devices. 
All traffic control devices erected and in place on all city streets within the city as of April 1, 2006 shall be deemed valid for all purposes in the location where the same have been erected, and the violation of any such device by any person shall be deemed a violation of the applicable state control law pertaining to such device. 
(Ord. No. 06-14, § 1, 4-25-06)  
Sec. 82-31. - One-way streets. 
The following streets, roadways and avenues shall be designated as a one-way: 
(1)  East Maritana Drive between 35th Avenue and 36th Avenue. 
(2)  22nd Avenue west bound between Gulf Way and Pass-a-Grille Way. 
(3)  16th Avenue west bound between Gulf Way and Pass-a-Grille Way. 
(4)  15th Avenue east bound between Gulf Way and Pass-a-Grille Way. 
(5)  9th Avenue east bound between Gulf Way and Pass-a-Grille Way. 
(6)  El Centro south bound between 37th Avenue and 35th Avenue. 
(7)  10th Avenue westbound between Pass-a-Grille Way and Gulf Way. 
(8)  Alley between 16th Avenue and 17th Avenue. 
(Ord. No. 98-76, § 1, 12-15-98; Ord. No. 99-40, § 1, 8-3-99; Ord. No. 06-16, § 1, 5-9-06; Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 10-30, § 1, 9-28-10)  
Secs. 82-3282-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - SPEED LIMITS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 02-08, § 1, adopted Feb. 19, 2002, repealed former §§ 82-6182-65, which pertained to posting; fifteen miles per hour; twenty miles per hour; twenty-five miles per hour; thirty-five miles per hour. Section 2 of said ordinance enacted provisions designated as § 82-61 to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 
State Law reference Speed limits generally, F.S. §§ 316.183316.1906; municipal authority as to speed limits, F.S. §§ 316.007, 316.008(1)(j), 316.189. 
 
Sec. 82-61. - Speed limits. 
(a)  The applicable speed limit for all city streets within the city shall be 30 miles per hour for all commercial areas and 25 miles per hour for all residential areas, unless otherwise provided by ordinance. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) hereof, the following speed limits shall be applicable on the following city streets:

41st Avenue 	From Belle Vista Drive to Poinsettia Drive 
Belle Vista Drive 	From 39th Avenue to Oleander Way 
 
(c)  The city manager shall post appropriate speed limit signs that meet the requirements of state law for all speed limits established in this section. All speed limits in effect at the time of adoption of this section shall remain effective unless amended hereby or hereafter by ordinance. It shall be unlawful for any person to exceed any speed limit established under this section. 
(Ord. No. 02-08, § 2, 2-19-02; Ord. No. 06-14, § 2, 4-25-06)
