ARTICLE II. - DRAINAGE REGULATIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166; drainage generally, F.S. ch. 298; adoption or amendment of land development regulations, F.S. § 163.3194. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 106-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Absorption area means any area, designed or natural, capable of allowing stormwater percolation. 
Building means any structure built for the support, shelter or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels or property of any kind which has enclosing walls for 50 percent of its perimeter. The term "building" shall be construed as if followed by the phrase "or part thereof." For the purpose of this article, each portion of a building separated from other portions by a firewall shall be considered as a separate building. 
City engineer means the person responsible for reviewing drainage plans for the city and enforcing the provisions and standards of this article. 
Department means the department of planning and development. 
Design storm means the storm frequency as outlined in the design criteria in sections 106-28 and 106-52 through 106-59. 
Detention means the collection and storage of surface water for subsequent controlled discharge at a rate which is less than the rate of inflow. 
Developer means any person engaged in any type of development of improved or unimproved land. 
Development means the construction or installation of a structure, impervious surface, drainage facility or part thereof of land, whether or not previously developed. 
Drainage facility means any component of the drainage system. 
Drainage plan means the detailed analysis required by sections 106-28 and 106-52 through 106-59. 
Drainage system means the system through which water flows from the land. It includes all storm drain lines, retention ponds and outfalls. 
Engineer, when used alone, means the registered professional engineer responsible for preparing the plans required under this article. 
Erosion means the damage caused by unrestricted surface waters which shall include the movement of silt, soils or foreign material. 
Flood means the inundation of areas not ordinarily covered by water. 
Grading means the moving of earth or materials for the purpose of development or redevelopment or the temporary or permanent alteration of existing topography of the land. 
Impervious surface means a surface which has been compacted or covered with a layer of material so that it is highly resistant to infiltration by water. The term includes most conventionally surfaced streets, roofs, sidewalks, parking lots, any granular material such as concrete, asphalt, crushed stone, rock, gravel or shell placed on an impervious base such as plastic, tarpaper, asphalt sealed shell or similar material which interferes with the natural ground absorption of stormwater and other similar structures. 
Improved land means the land that has been altered or improved from its natural state, including but not limited to grading, paving, drainage, installation of structures, etc., that ultimately increased the value of or altered the original integrity of the land. 
Lawful buildable area means the area of a site in which development, as defined in this section, can lawfully take place without variances. 
Owner means the person in whom is vested the fee ownership, domination or title of property, i.e., the proprietor. This term may also include a tenant, if chargeable under the lease for the maintenance of the property, and any agent of the owner or tenant. The term "owner" shall include a public entity when that entity has a right-of-way easement, interest or any ownership interest. 
Person means any and all persons, natural or artificial, and includes any individual, firm, corporation, governmental agency, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, association, two or more persons having a joint or common interest or any other legal entity. 
Sediment means solid material, whether mineral or organic, that is in suspension, and is being transported or has been moved from its site of origin. 
Sedimentation facility means any structure or area which is designed to hold runoff water until suspended sediments have settled. 
Site means any tract, lot or parcel or combination of tracts, lots or parcels of land which are in one ownership or are contiguous and in diverse ownership where development is to be performed as a part of a unit, subdivision or project or which is site planned as a whole. 
Structure means that which is built or constructed, an edifice or building of any kind or any piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts, joined together in some definite manner. The term "structure" shall be construed as if followed by the phrase "or part thereof." 
Subsurface drainage means any approved method used as a vehicle to transmit groundwater, such as under drains, perforated drains or storm drain lines. 
Unimproved land means the land that has not been altered or improved from its natural state, including but not limited to grading, paving, drainage, installation of structures, etc., that ultimately increased the value of or altered the original integrity of the land. 
Vegetation means all plant growth, especially trees, shrubs, vines, ferns, mosses and grasses. 
Water or community waters means any and all water on or beneath the surface of the ground or in the atmosphere. It includes the water in any watercourse, water body or drainage system. It also includes diffused surface water and water percolating, standing or flowing beneath the surface of the ground, as well as coastal waters. 
Water body means any natural or artificial pond, lake, reservoir or other area which ordinarily or intermittently contains water and which has a discernible shoreline. 
Watercourse means any natural or artificial stream, river, creek, channel, ditch, canal, conduit, culvert, drain, waterway, gully, ravine, street, roadway, swale or wash in which water flows in a definite channel, bed or banks. 
Watershed area means an area allowing or generating stormwater or irrigation water runoff. 
Wetlands means those areas where: 
(1)  The soil is ordinarily saturated with water; or 
(2)  Wetlands vegetation, as designated by the state department of environmental protection, is the dominant plant community. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 2; Code 1983, § 7-1; Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-1), 5-20-97) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 106-27. - Interpretation. 
If the requirements of this article be in conflict with any provision of chapter 134, pertaining to zoning, the provisions of this article shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 7(N); Code 1983, § 7-2; Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-2), 5-20-97)  
Sec. 106-28. - Compliance. 
(a)  Any development, redevelopment or alteration of a site, except as specified in sections 106-54 and 106-55, shall conform to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  If the development, redevelopment or alteration involves over 50 percent of the lawful buildable area of a previously developed site, or over one-half acre of the site, regardless of the percentage, the entire site shall conform to the requirements of this article as if the entire site has been developed. 
(c)  If the new development is on a previously undeveloped site, the entire site shall comply with the requirements of this article, regardless of the percentage of development. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 3; Code 1983, § 7-3(a); Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-3(a)), 5-20-97)  
Secs. 106-29106-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DRAINAGE PLAN 
 
Sec. 106-51. - Violations; maintenance; restoration. 
(a)  Any person who commences or conducts an activity described in sections 106-28 and 106-52 through 106-59 without prior approval of a drainage plan, deviates from an approved drainage plan or fails to maintain drainage facilities under the person's ownership or control shall be guilty of a violation of this article. The city may act to maintain such drainage facilities if the lack of maintenance constitutes a public nuisance. The cost of such maintenance shall then become a lien on the property on which the facilities are located. 
(b)  Any activity undertaken in violation of this article shall be halted immediately after written notice by the city. The violator may be required to restore any altered land to its undisturbed condition or restore it to such condition in which it would not shed stormwater in violation of the control requirements for stormwater runoff contained in this article. If restoration is not undertaken within a reasonable time and the alteration constitutes a public nuisance, the city may act to restore the property. The cost of the restoration shall then become a lien upon the property where such illegal activity occurred. 
(c)  The city shall follow the procedure set forth in chapter 46 in restoring property or maintaining drainage facilities and placing a lien on the property. 
(d)  If a pond or other water body is entirely surrounded by private property so that the general public does not have access to use and enjoy the water body, maintenance of such ponds or other water bodies shall be accomplished by the city only with respect to drainage as part of the overall drainage system of the city. If a public nuisance should be created as the result of a lack of maintenance of such pond or other water body, where it is entirely surrounded by private property owners, the city may carry out necessary maintenance and charge the cost of such maintenance to the abutting property owners. The city shall follow the procedure set forth in chapter 46 in maintaining such pond or water body and placing a lien on the property. 
(e)  For the purposes of this article it shall be conclusively presumed that a nuisance exists when one or more of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  Drainage facilities are not maintained properly so that as a result water has flooded or is reasonably likely to flood land not owned by the owner of the land on which the drainage facilities are located or water has flooded or is reasonably likely to flood a building whether or not located on land owned by the owner of the drainage facilities. 
(2)  Activity has been undertaken in violation of this article and as a result water has flooded or is reasonably likely to flood land not owned by the owner of the land on which the unlawful activity has taken place or a building or part thereof, whether or not located on land owned by the owner of the land on which the unlawful activity has taken place. 
(3)  A pond or other water body entirely surrounded by private property has not been properly maintained and as a result water has flooded or is reasonably likely to flood land other than that owned by the owners of land directly abutting such pond or water body or a building or part thereof, whether or not located on land owned by the owner of land directly abutting such pond or body of water. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 6; Code 1983, § 7-5; Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-5), 5-20-97)  
Sec. 106-52. - Approval required prior to development; submission of plan. 
(a)  Prior to development or grading and land balancing of any land specified in this division, approval of a drainage plan shall be obtained from the city engineer. The city engineer shall not be required to approve such a plan until site plan approval and, as required, plat approval has been obtained. Issuance of this approval is contingent upon the requirements of this article. 
(b)  The developer shall submit to the department of planning and development two copies of a drainage plan prepared by a professional engineer. At the time of the submission of a drainage plan, the applicant shall pay the city a filing fee as established by resolution of the city commission and listed in the fee schedule in appendix A to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 3; Code 1983, § 7-3(b)(1); Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-3(b)(1)), 5-20-97)  
Sec. 106-53. - Information required. 
(a)  The drainage plan shall provide an up-to-date survey of the proposed land to be developed, redeveloped or graded and land balanced showing the number and location of existing trees; adequate elevations or contours to determine the existing and proposed drainage patterns; and all ditches, canals, streams, storm sewers and all other key topographic features located within or directly adjacent to or serving the land to be developed or cleared. The calculations for runoff, detention and pipe sizes shall be submitted. The department may require such additional information as deemed necessary to determine if the plan meets the requirements of this article. 
(b)  The drainage plan shall also contain the following: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the owner, engineer and the developer. In addition, the legal description of the property shall be provided. 
(2)  A plan for the control of erosion and sedimentation which specifies in detail the type and location of control measures, the stage of development at which they will be put into place or used and provisions for the maintenance of them. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 3; Code 1983, § 7-3(b)(2); Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-3(b)(2)), 5-20-97)  
Sec. 106-54. - Single-family homes and duplexes. 
The owner of an individual single-family home or duplex shall not be required to submit formal drainage plans in accordance with the requirements of sections 106-52(b) and 106-53 but shall be governed by the following requirements: 
(1)  The maximum lot area covered by impervious surfaces, including the principal building and all accessory structures, driveways, walkways, swimming pools and docks and other structures or materials which prevent the infiltration of water into the ground, shall be limited to 70 percent of the net buildable lot, excluding any portion of the property lying seaward of the city's coastal construction setback line. 
(2)  Swales shall be required along all property lines that are not contiguous with public rights-of-way and shall be graded to direct stormwater runoff into either the street or into a waterway. 
(3)  Gutters and downspouts shall be required on all roof eaves that are within five feet of a property line adjacent to a neighboring property. 
(4)  There shall be no fill used as structural support higher than 16 inches above the crown in the road with the exception that the interior of stemwall construction may be filled. Noncompacted fill may be used around the perimeter of a building for landscaping or aesthetic purposes provided the fill has the ability to wash out during storm surge, thereby rendering the building free of obstruction prior to generating excessive loading forces, ramping effects, or wave deflection. The building official shall approve design plans for landscaping or aesthetic fill only after the applicant has provided an analysis by a certified engineer, architect, or soil scientists, which demonstrates that the following factors have been fully considered: 
a.  Particle composition of fill material does not have a tendency for excessive natural compaction; 
b.  Volume and distribution of fill will not cause wave defection to adjacent properties; and 
c.  Slope of fill will not cause wave run-up or ramping. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 3; Code 1983, § 7-3(b)(3); Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-3(b)(3)), 5-20-97; Ord. No. 99-53, § 1, 9-21-99; Ord. No. 00-35, § 1, 8-1-00)  
Sec. 106-55. - Minor additions, alterations or improvements to existing development. 
Minor additions and alterations to an existing development are exempted from the requirements of sections 106-52(b) and 106-53. For the purpose of this article, a minor addition, alteration or improvement is defined as an addition which increases existing gross floor by no more than five percent or vehicular use areas by ten percent or alterations and repairs, the cost of which in the aggregate does not exceed or equal 25 percent of the permit value assessment of the structure before the first improvement is started or, if the structure has been damaged and being restored, before the damage occurred. Removal and replacement of impervious surface cover with a permeable cover shall be credited towards the minor addition, alteration or improvement thresholds set forth in this section. Such credit shall be subtracted as a square footage or dollar amount, whichever is applicable, prior to calculation of the appropriate threshold percentages. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 3; Code 1983, § 7-3(b)(4); Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-3(b)(4)), 5-20-97)  
Sec. 106-56. - Fee payment in lieu of drainage improvements. 
Some existing developments undergoing additions, alterations or improvements which exceed the thresholds described in section 106-55 may be permitted to pay a fee in lieu of installing drainage improvements when it is determined by the city that the requirements of this article are impractical or impossible to construct on the site. All such determinations shall be made on a case-by-case basis. The amount of the fee shall be based on an amount per square foot of the entire site, such amount to be established by resolution of the city commission and is listed in appendix A to this Code. Moneys collected under this section shall be used by the city to make upgrades, improvements and extensions of the existing drainage system. In no case shall this provision be permitted where the intent of this article can be met. 
(Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-3(b)(5)), 5-20-97)  
Sec. 106-57. - Review. 
The drainage plan will be reviewed by the department within 60 days of receipt unless other reviews required by ordinance require more time, in which case the time shall extend 60 days beyond completion of such review. If the drainage plan is in compliance with the requirements of this Code and this article, approval shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 3; Code 1983, § 7-3(c); Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-3(c)), 5-20-97)  
Sec. 106-58. - Inspection of improvements. 
Upon completion of improvements under this article, the city engineer shall inspect the site for compliance with the approved plan. A certificate of compliance must be issued by the inspection officer before a certificate of occupancy can be issued for any related structure or before any paved access (curb cuts) to public streets from the site may be granted. If the application is for grading and land balancing only and no structure or paving is specified, a certificate of compliance must be issued if a financial guarantee acceptable in form to the city attorney and in the amount approved by the city manager is provided. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 3; Code 1983, § 7-3(d); Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-3(d)), 5-20-97)  
Sec. 106-59. - Approval criteria and procedures. 
(a)  Drainage plans shall be approved only if they demonstrate that the proposed development or grading and land balancing has been planned and designed and will be constructed and maintained to meet the standards in this section. 
(b)  No development or redevelopment of a site shall cause the rate of stormwater discharge to be released from the post-developed site to exceed the rate of stormwater discharge of the predeveloped site. Additional stormwater discharge created by the development or redevelopment of the site shall be retained on-site and released at a rate no greater than the rate of the predeveloped site. 
(c)  If there is an absence of data to adequately determine the "natural unimproved state," such as a redevelopment project, the existing runoff discharge may be calculated using a runoff coefficient of 0.3. 
(d)  The proposed development or grading and land balancing shall not allow erosion or flooding to effect any significant damage to adjacent areas during or after construction. 
(e)  In determining runoff, pipe sizes, detention requirements, etc., for the site to be developed, the following criteria and methods shall be used: 
(1)  Criteria for calculating stormwater runoff. 
a.  The maximum rate of runoff released from a site and the required retention volume shall be calculated using the rational formula as follows: 
Q = Cia 
Where: 
Q 	is the rate of runoff in cubic feet per second; 
C 	is the coefficient of runoff; 
i 	is the intensity of rainfall in inches per hour, pursuant to the current state department of transportation rainfall intensity curves for zone VI, using a ten-year, one-hour design storm; and 
a 	is the drainage areas in acres. 
 
Other formulas, where appropriate, as described in the Basis for Review for Surface Water Management Applications within the Southwest Florida Water Management District, may be used when such other formulas are acceptable to the city engineer. 
b.  The coefficient of runoff shall be determined by the type of existing and future development, the soil characteristics and the topography of the land. The following table listing the general ranges shall be used, subject to variation in accordance with generally accepted scientific principles: 
Lawns: 	
	Sandy soil, flat (2% slope) 	0.100.15 
	Sandy soil, average (2%7% slope) 	0.150.20 
	Clayey soil, flat (2% slope) 	0.140.20 
	Clayey soil, average (2%7% slope) 	0.200.30 
Commercial: 	
	Downtown areas 	0.700.95 
	Neighborhood areas 	0.500.70 
Residential: 	
	Single-family areas 	0.300.50 
	Multi-units, detached 	0.400.60 
	Multi-units, attached 	0.600.70 
	Apartment dwelling areas 	0.500.70 
Industrial: 	
	Light 	0.500.80 
	Heavy 	0.600.90 
Parks 	0.100.25 
Playgrounds 	0.200.35 
Unimproved areas 	0.100.30 
Streets and vehicular use areas: 	
	Asphalt 	0.700.95 
	Concrete 	0.800.95 
	Brick 	0.600.80 
Drives and walks 	0.750.85 
Roofs 	0.750.95 
 
c.  The criteria for determining the rainfall intensity shall be the current state department of transportation rainfall intensity curves for zone VI, Tampa. The time of concentration shall be based on the department of transportation velocity of runoff curves or other proven engineering methods, as approved by the city engineer. 
(2)  Stormwater detention. All proposed detention areas shall be designed using the recommended criteria listed in subsection (e)(1) of this section and design calculation shall be submitted with the site plan. Detention areas shall be designed, where possible, so that they will be completely dry within three days. Detention areas that contain water continuously or more than three days following rain shall be designed, to the maximum extent possible, to provide for maintenance of aquatic life to destroy mosquito larva. 
(3)  Approved methods of water detention. Design of proposed detention areas shall be in accordance with best management practices as follows and approved by the city engineer: 
a.  Detention pond. Surface area, depth, bank slopes and outfall shall be designed according to site requirements and department standards. 
b.  Grass, loose rock or landscaped absorption areas. Surface area, configuration and type shall be designed according to site requirements and department standards. 
c.  Grass, loose rock or landscaped absorption areas. Surface area, configuration and type shall be designed according to site requirements and shall be subject to review by the city engineer and his approval. A percolation test shall be required to verify ground absorption capabilities. 
d.  Subsurface drain or percolation field. Length, size and depth of drainpipe, size and type filter material and location of field shall be designed according to site requirements, and shall be subject to the review and approval of the city engineer. A percolation test shall be required to verify ground absorption capabilities. 
e.  Vehicular use areas designed with restrictive stormwater inlets or restrictive pipe sizes. Parking areas shall be designed with sufficient detention areas that, when used in conjunction with a restrictive storm sewer system, shall control the volume of water runoff to conform with this section. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 3; Code 1983, § 7-3(e); Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-3(e)), 5-20-97)  
Sec. 106-60. - Variances. 
(a)  Where strict adherence to this article is impossible or impractical to enforce, the appropriate board of authority may, upon receipt of a written request, authorize a variance. However, such variance shall be limited to the minimum variance required to make adherence to this article possible and practical. Any request for a variance to this article shall be submitted in writing and shall clearly and in detail state what adjustment is warranted. The appeal shall be accompanied by a processing fee as set by ordinance. The criteria for variances contained in article II of chapter 22 shall apply to such application for a variance. The notice provisions and procedures contained in article II of chapter 22 shall be followed by the applicant and the board. The appropriate board of authority shall not act without first having received a written analysis of the facts of the appeal from the director. 
(b)  Within 15 days after action of the appropriate board of authority, but not thereafter, their decision may be appealed to the circuit court as provided by article II of chapter 22; otherwise, the decision of the appropriate board of authority becomes final. 
(Ord. No. 81-48, § 4; Code 1983, § 7-4; Ord. No. 97-14, § 1(7-4), 5-20-97)  
Secs. 106-61106-85. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STORM WATER[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note At the request of the city, Ord. No. 99-71, §§ 19, adopted Dec. 21, 1999, has been included herein as Art. III, §§ 106-86106-94. See the Code Comparative Table. 
 
Sec. 106-86. - Intent. 
This article is hereby adopted by the City of St. Pete Beach for the purpose of maintaining efficient, economic, and safe operation of the separate storm sewer system, and for the protection of the health, safety, and general welfare of the public within the City of St. Pete Beach. This article is intended to prevent and abate pollution through the regulation and control of connections and discharges to the City of St. Pete Beach's Separate Storm Sewer System and to limit the use of the City of St. Pete Beach's Separate Sewer System to the collection, conveyance, treatment, and disposal of storm water through appropriate regulation and enforcement. The prohibitive discharge standards contained herein were developed under the authority of Section 5 of the Act and 40 CFR 122, applicable DEP, SWFWMD regulations and applicable home rule power. 
(Ord. No. 99-71, § 1, 12-21-99)  
Sec. 106-87. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply to the provisions of this article: 
Authorized official means any employee or agent of the City of St. Pete Beach authorized in writing by the city manager to administer or enforce the provisions of this article. 
City manager means the City Manager of the City of St. Pete Beach, Florida. 
Discharge means any direct introduction of any solid, liquid, or gaseous matter. 
Illicit discharge means any discharge to the City of St. Pete Beach's Separate Storm Sewer System that is not composed entirely of storm water except discharges pursuant to a NPDES permit (other than the NPDES permit for discharges from the separate storm sewer system) and discharges resulting from fire fighting activities. 
Person means any natural individual, corporation, partnership, institution, or other entity. 
Site of industrial activity means any area of facility used for manufacturing, processing or raw materials storage, as defined under 40 CFR Section 122.26(b)(14) of regulations of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, as amended. 
Storm water means any storm water runoff, and surface runoff, drainage, and any storm water defined by 40 CFR Parts 122, 123 and 124 Supplementary Information VI(b). 
Separate storm sewer system means the system of conveyances owned by the City of St. Pete Beach used for collecting, storing and transporting storm water but not including any facilities intended to be used in accordance with applicable law for collecting and transporting sanitary or other wastewater. 
(Ord. No. 99-71, § x, 12-21-99)  
Sec. 106-88. - Industrial activity. 
(a)  General prohibitions. Any discharge into the separate storm sewer system in violation of any federal (including 40 CFR Part 122), state, water management district, county, municipal or other law, rule, regulation or permit is prohibited. 
(b)  Specific prohibitions. By adoption of industrial activity storm water regulations or by issuance of industrial activity storm water permits or both, the City of St. Pete Beach's City Commission may impose reasonable limitations as to the quality of storm water (included without limitation the designation of maximum levels of pollutants) discharged into the separate storm sewer system from sites of Industrial activity. Any promulgation of such regulations and issuance of permits by the City of St. Pete Beach's City Commission shall be in accordance with applicable law. 
(c)  NPDES permits. Any person who holds a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit shall provide a copy of such permit to the city manager no later than the later of: 60 calendar days after the effective date of this article or 60 calendar days after issuance. 
(Ord. No. 99-71, § 3, 12-21-99)  
Sec. 106-89. - Illicit discharges. 
(a)  General prohibitions. Except as set forth under subsection (c) of this section or as in accordance with a valid NPDES permit, any discharge to the separate storm sewer system that is not composed entirely of storm water is prohibited. 
(b)  Specific prohibitions. Any discharge to the separate storm sewer system containing any sewage, industrial waste, or other waste materials, or containing any materials in violation of federal, state, county, municipal, or other laws, rules, regulations, order or permits, is prohibited. 
(c)  Authorized exceptions. The following discharges are exempt from the general prohibition set forth under paragraph (a) of this section: flows from fire fighting, water line flushing and other contributions from potable water sources, landscape irrigation and lawn watering, irrigation water, diverted stream flows, rising groundwater, direct infiltration to the separate storm sewer system, uncontaminated pumped groundwater, foundation and footing drains, water from crawl space pumps, air conditioning condensation, springs, individual residential car washings and flows from riparian habitats and wetlands. 
(d)  Illicit connections. No person may maintain, use or establish any direct or indirect connection to the separate storm sewer system that results in any discharge in violation of this article. This prohibition applies to connections made in the past, regardless of whether made under a permit, or other authorization, or whether permissible under laws or practices applicable or prevailing at the time the connection was made. 
(Ord. No. 99-71, § 4, 12-21-99)  
Sec. 106-90. - Spills and dumping. 
(a)  General prohibitions. Except as set forth under section 106-89(c) of this article or as in accordance with a valid NPDES permit, any discharge to the separate storm sewer system that is not composed entirely of storm water is prohibited. 
(b)  Specific prohibitions. Any discharge to the separate storm system containing any sewage, industrial waste, or other waste materials, or containing any materials in violation of federal, state, county, municipal, or other laws, rules, regulations, order or permits, is prohibited. 
(c)  Notification of spills. As soon as any person has knowledge of any discharge to the separate storm sewer system in violation of this article, such person shall immediately notify the city manager and if such Person is directly or indirectly responsible for such discharge, then such person shall also take immediate action to ensure the containment and clean up of such discharge and shall confirm such telephone notification in writing to the City Manager at City of St. Pete Beach City Hall, 7701 Boca Ciega Dr., St. Pete Beach, Florida 33706, within three calendar days. 
(Ord. No. 99-71, § 5, 12-21-99)  
Sec. 106-91. - Inspections and monitoring. 
(a)  Authority for inspections. Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of this article, or regulation, or permit issued hereunder, or whenever an authorized official has reasonable cause to believe there exists any condition constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or regulation or permit issued hereunder, any authorized official may enter any property, building or facility at any reasonable time to inspect the same or to perform any duty related to enforcement of the provisions of this article or regulations or permits used hereunder; provided that (1) if such property, building, or facility is occupied, such authorized official shall first present proper credentials and request permission to enter, and (2) if such property, building, or facility is unoccupied, such authorized official shall make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other person having charge or control of the property, building or facility, and shall request permission to enter. Any request for permission to enter made hereunder shall state that the owner or person in control has the right to refuse entry, and that in such event that entry is refused, the authorized official may enter to make inspection only upon issuance of a search warrant by a duly authorized magistrate. If the owner or person in control refuses permission to enter after such request has been made, the authorized official is hereby authorized to seek assistance from any court of competent jurisdiction in obtaining entry. Routine or area-wide inspections shall be based upon such reasonable selection processes as may be necessary to carry out the purposes of this article, including but not limited to random sampling and sampling in areas with evidence of storm water contamination, non-storm water discharge or similar factors. 
(b)  Authority for monitoring and sampling. Any authorized official may install and maintain such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling or metering of discharges to the separate storm sewer system. During any inspections made to enforce the provisions of this article or regulations or permits issued hereunder, any authorized official may take any samples deemed necessary. 
(c)  Requirements for monitoring. The city manager or authorized official may require any person engaging in any activity or owning any property, building or facility (including but not limited to a site of industrial activity) to undertake such reasonable monitoring of any discharge(s) to the separate storm sewer system and to furnish periodic reports. 
(Ord. No. 99-71, § 6, 12-21-99)  
Sec. 106-92. - Administrative order. 
The city manager may issue an order to any person to immediately cease any discharge, or eliminate any connection to the separate storm sewer system, determined by the city manager to be in violation of any provision of this article, or in violation of any regulation or permit issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 99-71, § 7, 12-21-99)  
Sec. 106-93. - Penalties. 
Failure to comply with the requirements of this article or any permit or approval granted or authorized hereunder shall constitute a violation of this article. Violations of this article shall upon conviction be punished as provided in 1-14 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 99-71, § 8, 12-21-99)  
Sec. 106-94. - Civil remedies. 
In addition to the penalties provided in section 106-93, the City of St. Pete Beach's City Commission is hereby authorized to institute any appropriate action or proceeding, including suite for injunctive relief, in order to prevent or abate violations of this article; and the city shall be entitled to recover a civil penalty for each violation of this article in an amount not more than $5,000.00 for each offense. If a violation is continued, each day of such violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 99-71, § 9, 12-21-99)  
Secs. 106-95106-152. - Reserved.  
Chapter 118 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 118-1118-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COMPREHENSIVE PLAN 
 
Sec. 118-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Comprehensive development plan means a long-range or master plan for the physical development of the city and those environs reasonably expected within the next 20 years or so to become a physical part of the city either through annexation or a close interrelationship resulting from the normal and expected economic development of the area, such plan among other things to provide for present and future vehicular traffic and other transportation arteries and terminals; a well-ordered design for future use and reuse of land; order for the healthful and convenient location of population to prevent undue concentration in parts or under-population in others; the promotion of good civic design in buildings and structures, and useful and aesthetic arrangement of open spaces; efficiency in the location of public buildings; and wise and efficient expenditure of public funds for capital improvements of the physical facilities of the city, all features of such plan to be assembled and maintained in a document or series of documents and maps and other descriptive matter. 
Official map means a map, but not the zoning map, including and designating certain features of the comprehensive plan that have been officially adopted by the city commission for enforcement through such powers and influence then available that the city is able to exercise in effecting the plan. Among other features, the official map may show existing rights-of-way, setback lines for future widening of street rights-of-way, and proposed sites for public parks, playgrounds, buildings, and other facilities. 
Subdivision means a division of a lot, tract, or parcel of land, whether improved or unimproved, into two or more lots or parcels of land, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or development or, if the establishment of a new street is involved, any division of such parcel, providing that any division of land into parcels of more than three acres not involving any change in street lines or public easements shall not be deemed to be a subdivision within the meaning of this article. The term includes a resubdivision as well as initial subdivision. 
Subdivision ordinance means an ordinance, duly adopted by the city commission, regulating and establishing standards for the subdivision of land within the city, as provided in chapter 126. 
Zoning plan means a legal document duly adopted by the city commission consisting of a written text and a zoning map regulating the use of land, the size, location and height of buildings, and the density of population within the city, as provided in chapter 134. 
(Code 1960, § 2-17; Ord. No. 114, § 1; Ord. No. 412; Code 1983, § 17-1) 
Cross reference Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 118-27. - Adopted. 
The city adopts by reference the comprehensive plan, as amended through the adoption date of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 2-21; Ord. No. 81-19, § 1; Code 1983, § 17-2; Ord. No. 89-25, § 1, 11-7-89) 
State Law reference Adoption of comprehensive plan, F.S. § 163.3161(6); amendment of comprehensive plan, F.S. § 163.3187.  
Sec. 118-28. - Public participation in comprehensive planning process. 
The city shall comply with all local ordinances and state statutes pertaining to public participation in the comprehensive planning process. 
(Code 1983, § 17-2.1; Ord. No. 2016-20, § 2, 10-11-16)  
Sec. 118-29. - City street name map. 
(a)  A street name map of the city, which shall include all legally established streets, street names, alleys, and other rights-of-way, whether established by plat, dedication or other method, shall be prepared by the city and be maintained on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  An address ranges schedule shall be attached as schedule A to the city street name map maintained by the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1960, § 2-22; Ord. No. 114, § 6; Ord. No. 11; Code 1983, § 17-3; Ord. No. 95-23, § 1, 6-20-95; Ord. No. 95-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-17-95) 
Editor's note The attachment is not set out in this article, but is on file and available for inspection in the city clerk's office.

(Code 1960, § 2-23; Ord. No. 82-33, § 1; Ord. No. 329, §§ 14; Ord. No. 81-38, §§ 1, 2; Code 1983, § 17-4; Ord. No. 86-11, § 1, 5-20-86; Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, 9-17-91; Ord. No. 91-36, § 1, 11-5-91)
